Prompt: How might we apply AI to promote environmental sustainability and combat climate change?
Description: AI can be a powerful tool in the fight against climate change and the promotion of environmental sustainability. Machine learning algorithms can analyze satellite imagery and sensor data to monitor deforestation, track wildlife populations, and detect changes in land use patterns. AI can also optimize renewable energy systems by predicting energy demand, optimizing power generation and distribution, and improving the efficiency of energy storage technologies. In agriculture, AI-powered precision farming techniques can help reduce water and pesticide use while maximizing crop yields. By providing insights and optimizations across various sectors, AI can support more sustainable and environmentally friendly practices on a global scale.
EXPO Day 1: Problem Card Prompts: Problem Title  Deforestation  Problem Description  Climate change and environmental sustainability are significant challenges facing our planet. These include deforestation, changes in land use patterns, and the decline of wildlife populations. Additionally, there are inefficiencies in renewable energy systems and agricultural practices that contribute to environmental degradation and climate change.

Prompt: How might we harvest energy and shield against radiation with melanin?
Description: Commercial aircraft use about 100 MW of electricity. All that electricity must be generated by the aircraft. This require converting fuel to electricity that results in a reduction of aircraft efficiency. If some portion of that energy could be harvested without the expenditure of fuel that would increase aircraft efficiency. Aircraft operate at high altitudes where UV radiation and cosmic radiation levels are much greater than at ground level. This radiation represents a source of energy that remains unharvested. This free energy could be used to increase the energy efficiency of aircraft while reducing passenger exposure to harmful radiation Melanin is known mostly as a pigment but is a multifunctional material that accels at adsorbing UV and cosmic radiation that make it ideal for energy harvesting applications.  Melanin panels could harvest energy to supplement power. "Wicked-Wild" Idea  Investigate the ability of natural and synthetic melanin s to adsorb energy and produce electricity  for aerospace applications.

Prompt: How might we eliminate carbon emissions with High-temperature PEM Fuel Cell for Aviation?
Description: Opportunity  1) To eliminate CO2 emission 2) To triple energy efficiency CO2 production by hydrocarbon fueled aircraft that contributes to global warming is expected to triple by 2050. Continuing to fuel aircraft with hydrocarbons is not sustainable.  Replacing hydrocarbon fuel with H2 eliminates CO2 emission. Joint NACA NASA - Air Force projects Bee and Suntan successfully flew a B-57B twin-engine bomber using liquid hydrogen (LH2),  and successfully fueled MW-scale aircraft engines (CW J-65 and P W M304) using LH2 in the 1950s. Because LH2 volumetric energy density is 25  of jet fuel, H2 powered aircraft requires a much larger fuel tank. Replacing the combustion process with higher energy efficiency fuel cell electrochemical reaction may offset the lower LH2 energy density. The current PEM fuel cell energy efficiency ( 50 ) is  2X an internal combustion engine. The estimated efficiency of high temperature PEM fuel cell (HT PEM FC) is  70 . The DOE is developing HT-PEM technologies for heavy duty vehicles but excludes considerations specific to aviation.  "Wicked-Wild" Idea  Develop HT-PEM technology for aviation  Using HT-PEM fuel cells to power electric aircraft eliminates CO2 emissions while sustaining timely, long-distance travel capability.   Develop HT-PEM fuel cell materials specifically for aviation   Focus on membranes, electrodes, and membrane electrode assemblies (MEA)  Include other stack components as opportunities allow  Test HT-PEM fuel cell materials, single cells, and cell stacks under aviation load profiles (high-power flight condition for take off and climb, low ambient air temperature and very dry air at high elevation, etc.)  Demonstrate HT-PEM FC energy efficiency and CO2 emission reductions
EXPO Day 1: Solution Card Prompts: Optimization of High Voltage Cables for Electrified Propulsion. This project proposes molecular dynamics simulations to optimize Cu-coated carbon nanotube (CNT) composites for lightweight, high voltage aircraft cables. Aiming for over 20  weight reduction, the study will refine Cu deposition on CNTs to achieve uniform coatings and consistent cable properties, supporting the development of more energy-dense, electrified propulsion systems in line with green aviation goals. Source  TTT Green Aviation proposal

Prompt: Hydrogen Fuel Aerogel Storage Tanks (HyFAST)
Description: Current challenges to (zero carbon) Hydrogen Aircraft fuel storage development often becomes a materials science engineering issue. Hydrogen poses challenges related to material compatibility, as it can cause hydrogen embrittlement in certain metals used for cryotanks. This can impact the structural integrity of components over time, necessitating the development of materials that can withstand prolonged exposure to hydrogen. Also, hydrogen is highly flammable, and safety is a paramount concern, especially in the aviation industry. In addition to these materials issues, hydrogen storage also creates a challenge for volume occupation and transport safety. What if we could accelerate beyond hydrocarbon fuels by  improving hydrogen fuel storage, aircraft safety, and efficiency using lightweight polymer aerogels Utilize porous polymer aerogels as a host system for safer, more efficient hydrogen fuel storage Incorporate aerogels into the construction of external hydrogen storage tanks for structural enhancement, vibration damping, and fire retardancy

Description: Opportunity  Sustainable aviation is a key initiative for NASA and the world to address climate change and protect the environment. An opportunity is presented to leverage inherent thermal generation in aircraft operation, typically seen as waste, to support electrification efforts and power the next generation of sustainable aviation. Leverage energy harvesting systems to support aircraft functions, optimize operational and energy efficiency through integrated systems, improve safety, and reduce waste. Energy harvesting technologies and advanced materials are available, along with an opportunity to drive change in advanced air mobility and electrified aircraft propulsion.

Prompt: Battery Pack Modelling
Description: Battery Pack Modelling Proposal Electro-Chemical   Structural-Thermal pack modelling proposal for TTT   Green Aviation Call, 2023 1) Problem, Objectives, Approach, and Anticipated Benefits  Many of novel aircraft concepts include some degree of electrification to reduce carbon footprint. To date, the battery models that have been able to be incorporated into NASA aircraft preliminary design studies such as the quadrotor0F 1 have been cell-level models1F 2, with knockdown factors for pack-level effects. There is an interest from EPFD, TTT, AATT, and other projects, in being able to more accurately model and optimize pack-level structural and thermal effects in addition to the cell-level effects. However, to date, there was no clear path on how this could be accomplished while still being compatible with cutting edge gradient-based aircraft optimization tools like OpenMDAO2F 3 and Aviary3F 4. The objective of this research proposal is to create an open-source battery pack model that includes cell electro-chemical effects as well as pack-level structural-thermal effects. The resulting model will be differentiable to ensure compatibility with OpenMDAO and Aviary. Our approach is to create a multi-center team and use open-source tools that we are already familiar with to create a system-level battery pack design. Figure 1 shows an Extended Design Structure Matrix (XDSM) diagram that details of how each of the component disciplines fits together to make the overall battery-pack model. In Figure 1, Discharge curves from cell-tests are input into the cell electro-chemical model which allows for the configuration of the parameters of the cell and later analysis. The cell electro-chemical effects based on models from ProgPy4F 5. A CAD model of the pack (multiple cells) is then created and imported along with the number of packs into the structural-thermal model TACS5F 6. The TACS software performs structural analysis to evaluate the mass of the pack as well as configure parameters for use later in the analysis. At this point the battery pack will be run through a sample mission which will primarily consist of pulling a specified quantity of amps at a particular voltage from the system over a given amount of time. During the mission, the cell electro-chemical model will keep track of the state of charge and voltage of the cells. TACS will keep track of the temperature throughout the pack subject to the heat produced by each cell and a assuming a constant cooling flow. Figure 2 (left) shows an example compliant battery pack designed and (right) a TACS structural-thermal pack model. Both of these models were designed by team members on this proposal. 1 E. Hendricks, E. Aretskin-Hariton, D. Ingraham, J. Gray, S. Schnulo, J. Chin, R. Falck, and D. Hall,  Multidisciplinary Optimization of an Electric Quadrotor Urban Air Mobility Aircraft,  in Aiaa 2020 aviation forum, 2020. 2 J. C. Chin, E. Aretskin-Hariton, D. Ingraham, D. Hall, S. L. Schnulo, J. S. Gray, and E. Hendricks,  Battery Evaluation Profiles for X-57 and Future Urban Electric Aircraft,  in Aiaa propulsion and energy forum, , 2020. 3 J. S. Gray, J. T. Hwang, J. R. R. A. Martins, K. T. Moore, and B. A. Naylor,  OpenMDAO  An Open-Source Framework for Multidisciplinary Design, Analysis, and Optimization,  Structural and Multidisciplinary Optimization, 2019. 4 Aviary will be a preliminary design tool for aircraft capable of modeling traditional and novel designs. This tool is built on top of OpenMDAO and will be Open Source and will provide easy-to-follow examples that will support both analysis and optimization. Aviary is scheduled for public release in December of 2024. 5 C. Teubert, K. Jarvis, M. Corbetta, C. Kulkarni, P. Banerjee, M. Daigle, ProgPy Python Prognostics Packages, v1.5, May 2023. URL nasa progpy. doi  10.5281 ZENODO.8097013 6 Kennedy, G. J. and Martins, J. R. R. A, "A parallel finite-element framework for large-scale gradient-based design optimization of high-performance structures", Finite Elements in Analysis and Design, 2014, doi http   dx.doi.org 10.1016 j.finel.2014.04.011 Figure 1, XDSM of Battery Pack Subsystems Figure 2, LEFT  CAD pack model, RIGHT  TACS Structural-Thermal Pack Model Benefits of this work would include creating a higher-fidelity battery pack model that can be used in aircraft system-level optimization by AATT, EPFD, TTT and other projects. This will enable better understanding of the trade-space for electrified aircraft studies. Additionally, by open sourcing the model and publishing a paper on it, this will provide other researchers in government, academia and industry with an understanding of how they can use the same methods to create their own higher fidelity battery pack models. 2) Milestones and how to Evaluate Success    January 2024   CAD Battery pack model completed   April 2024   Cell electro-chem model input constraints narrowed to decrease multimodality of solution space.   April 2024   Demonstrate TACS successfully ingesting CAD pack model and producing weights.   July 2024   Overall pack subsystem linked together, and first optimization   analysis run. Preliminary paperwork filed for open-source release. SciTech 2025 abstract submitted.   September 2024   Battery pack optimization completed. Optimization will vary wall thickness in one or more parts of the pack model. The optimization objective will be minimum mass while completing the mission objective based on a pre-determined voltage and amperage draw. Repository is released open source. 3) Next Steps and Areas for Transition  Completion of this work through open-source code release and publishing in SciTech 2025 would immediately enable TTT, AATT, and EPFD projects to use the pack-level model created to investigate specific battery pack and cell chemistries for electrified aircraft studies like the TTBW. This is a higher level of fidelity than they can currently achieve with the cell-only models that currently exist. Additionally, academic partners like U. Michigan, Georgia Tech, and Iowa State, could immediately take the models created from this work and integrate them into their electrified aircraft studies that they perform on an ongoing basis using simplified battery models. Further work would need to be performed in order to parameterize the pack-model into something that could handle changing the number of cells inside the pack without engineer input. CAD modelling of the pack, while useful for an initial design, is a time-consuming process that parametrization should help to simplify. Additionally, parameterization enables the optimizer to trade battery pack design for other aspects of the aircraft like thermal system mass and wing volume. 4) Challenge Scenario In the case where a subset of the analysis was infeasible, (i.e. if ProgPy was not capable of supplying the cell electro-chemical models but the other aspects of the thermal-structural analysis were working well,) we would use one of our other cell models or create a new cell model as a substitute. This scenario has happened multiple times in the past with other projects and we have been successful at finding substitute models. In the case where the entire approach was invalid, we could shift our focus to leveraging an already working battery cell model and enhancing it with better pack-level estimates for weight. While this would not be as thorough as analyzing the full structural-thermal system, it would still provide for increased fidelity which will provide useful for aircraft design studies. Regardless of what challenges appear before the team during this work, the entire team will be involved in the decision-making process of how to pivot and still create useful advancements in battery pack modelling for electrified aircraft design.

Prompt: Effects of Atmospheric Conditions and Sustainable Fuels on Contrail Radiative Forcing
Description: 1 TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS   TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL Title  Effects of Atmospheric Conditions and Sustainable Fuels on Contrail Radiative Forcing 1. Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated benefits). Executive summary Contrails create about two-thirds of aviation s contribution to climate change. To guarantee the success of contrail mitigation strategies such as flight altitude changes, the sensitivity of contrail optical depth to atmospheric parameters must be quantified with the associated uncertainty. Additionally, impact from both SAF and hydrogen needs to be studied  Are future aviation fuels more or less prone to contrails? We address these concerns by applying modeling, simulation, and uncertainty quantification (UQ) to contrails to assess and reduce the aviation s impact on global warming. What problem are you solving? Current estimates of the anthropogenic radiative forcing (RF) due to aviation are crippled by a very high level of uncertainty. This uncertainty comes from non-CO2 processes in the formation and persistence of contrails 1 . To address it rigorously, the influence of the local atmospheric conditions (which are only known up to a certain degree of confidence from weather models) must be propagated through contrail simulations. Similarly, the effect of the chemical composition of the jet exhaust gas (also a large source of uncertainty) must be factored in to enable predictions for different types of engines and fuels, such as SAF and H2, and unconventional aircraft technologies, such as Quesst. Eventually, we aim to predict the optical properties of the contrails and the related confidence interval, given uncertain inputs. Has someone tried to solve this problem before? If no one has attempted to solve this problem before, why not? Large Eddy Simulation (LES) of contrails has been performed in several research groups (reviewed in  2 ). The current state-of-the-art methodologies can handle contrails from conventional airplanes using regular jet fuels. To alleviate computational cost, contrail simulations typically use a time-developing framework, where the streamwise direction of the flow is replaced by periodicity conditions. Assuming Galilean invariance, the simulation is performed in a moving frame with a constant translation speed equal to the free stream velocity. Figure 1  Spatially developing wake simulation using VPM  3 .  2 Where did they go wrong? 1. No formal quantification of the uncertainty has been performed to date. At most, simple parametric studies have been conducted  4 . 2. Only few works have simulated contrails from SAF  5 , and virtually none from H2. There is a need to improve simulation codes and models so they can handle situations with fewer aerosols and or soot particles which in turn affect the nucleation and growth of ice particles. 3. The effect of the time-developing assumption on the simulation results has never been quantified. However, it impedes physical processes that involve axial velocities (since they are not Galilean invariant). Consequences on the mixing in the plume and the ensuing contrail RF must be studied. What is different about your approach? How does your proposed work transform current capabilities, tools methods or state-of-the art approaches? Our simulations will address the above shortcomings as follows  1. Use of QUEST (NASA UQ software) to propagate uncertainty through the simulations. 2. Use of a Lagrangian super particle approach to deal with the microphysics of ice nucleation in a variety of environments, with different concentration of aerosols soot particles and diverse background conditions (humidity, temperature, stratification, etc.), specifically targeting the microphysics of SAF and H2 contrails. 3. Use of a Vortex Particle-Mesh (VPM) approach to perform regular space developing simulations (as opposed to time-developing) at a moderate computational cost (Figure 1) and quantify the model error associated with the time-developing assumption by comparing with regular LES performed with the code NTMIX. In these efforts we will collaborate with Stanford Univ. (Dr. Tania Ferreira, Prof. Catherine Gorle, Prof. Juan Alonso) and Poly. Montreal (Prof. Roberto Paoli) to cross-validate our simulations and models. If successful, what does your proposed work enable that currently is unattainable? Our simulation results will lead to parameterizations and surrogate models based on machine learning (ML) techniques trained on our simulation results. Such models can then be used to improve climate models and devise efficient contrail mitigation strategies (see sect.3). Potential customers  FAA, airframe and engine manufacturers, policy planners, etc. 2. Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion.   Description Exit criteria 1 Generate high-fidelity LES of aircraft wakes in a stratified atmosphere   engine exhaust vapor depositing onto ice crystals (NTMIX code). Code working and validated against canonical benchmark. 2 Incorporate stratification and engine vapor into a VPM method for rapid predictions. Perform spatially developing simulations using VPM and compare with the time-developing LES results. Code working and validated against canonical benchmark. Time-developing model error quantified. 3 Vary ambient stratification, temperature, humidity, atmospheric turbulence, and fuel type. Use UQ to sample the parameter space and obtain uncertainty bounds. LES and VPM results compared and validated against observations (e.g., ND-MAX). 3 4 Extract a parametrization surrogate of contrail optical depth versus the atmospheric parameters for each fuel. Model available as a set of equations or a numerical implementation. 5 Analyze uncertainty with respect to the aerosol content and ice nucleation modes of hydrogen SAF combustion Study ready to be published disseminated. 3. After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps? Where are the potential areas for transition? What follow-on research do you anticipate?   Our parameterization should be implemented in global circulation models to better quantify the nonCO2 impact of aviation on climate change and the related uncertainty.   Air traffic trajectory should be optimized under uncertainty. Mitigating non-CO2 effects is challenging because it usually increases direct CO2 effects. Efficient strategies should use the information about uncertainty from our models to target the operational adaptations that have the highest likelihood of making a positive overall impact. This connects with the transition goals of ATM-X.   Future research should focus on reducing the uncertainty in the inputs to our models. One example is the predicted humidity at high altitude, which will require refinement of current weather simulation and forecasting methods. 4. Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation  Three months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach is not feasible technically. You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot? What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue? Let us first note that    Two independent simulation codes will be used  NTMIX and VPM. This mitigates the risk since it is highly unlikely that neither will work for the intended problem. Both codes have been used in the past for similar problems.   If UQ does not work with QUEST, other software can be used such as DAKOTA.   If ML does not work for the parameterization (e.g., because too much data is required to train the model), we can rely on more conventional method for surrogate modeling such as kriging. In the unlikely event that the initial approach is unfeasible because none of the simulation codes work, we could redirect the focus of this project in several ways. For example    Contrails can only persist in the atmosphere in ice super-saturated regions (ISSR). Predicting the position and spatial extent of these ISSR is notoriously difficult. We could work on improving the modeling of ISSR using a combination of numerical weather predictions, observational data, and machine learning.   The interaction between a contrail, the ensuing contrail cirrus, and natural cirrus clouds is not well understood. We could work on improving ice mixed cloud modeling using Lagrangian capabilities like those we envisioned for the proposed work. References   1  D.S. Lee, D.W. Fahey, A. Skowron, et al., The contribution of global aviation to anthropogenic climate forcing for 2000 to 2018, Atmospheric Environment, Volume 244, 117834, 2021.  2  Paoli, R.   Shariff, K. Contrail Modeling and Simulation, Annual Review of Fluid Mechanics, 48 393-427, 2015.  3  D.-G. Caprace, Modeling of lifting-dragging devices for large eddy simulation of space-developing wakes  application to wings, rotors and formation flight. PhD thesis, Universite Catholique de Louvain, 2020.  4  Unterstrasser, S. and Gierens, K.  Numerical simulations of contrail-to-cirrus transition   Part 1  An extensive parametric study, Atmos. Chem. Phys., 10, 2017 2036, 2010.  5  Voigt, C., Kleine, J., Sauer, D. et al. Cleaner burning aviation fuels can reduce contrail cloudiness. Commun Earth Environ 2, 114, 2021.

Zero-emission scalable quiet aircraft propulsion b. Has someone tried to solve this problem before? Yes, but with fuel cells, batteries, and hydrogen turbofans. c. Where did they go wrong? After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps? a. Venture capital funding to complete the prototype and establish a manufacturing company in the Cleveland area. b. Where are the potential areas for transition? This This zero-emission power generator can be used on all aircraft. c. What follow-on research do you anticipate? This technology, if successfully demonstrated, replaces fuel cells, batteries, and turbofans in future green aviation electric aircraft. 4. Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation  Three months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach is not feasible technically. You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot? a. What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue? i. Prompt: Improved Propulsion Airframe Integration (PAI) Simulations for Design, Analysis and Optimization of Both Airframe and Propulsor
Description: TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS   TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT   FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE   Title  Improved Propulsion Airframe Integration (PAI) Simulations for Design, Analysis and Optimization of Both Airframe and Propulsor   Description of the work    Propulsion Airframe Integration (PAI) at NASA is inadequate for addressing subsonic transport Mach numbers and higher, as well as distortion for blades with a lot of twist consistent of typical high bypass ratio turbofans for relatively quick design-study or optimization types of runs.  PAI capability for design understanding is critical for getting improved performance of aircraft and to meet key sustainability goals of NASA. The current codes have actuator disk capability for steady simulations which are inadequate or have the ability to run time accurate with rotating blades installed but require thousands of CPUs and thousands of CPU GPU hours to run.     The Sustainable Flight Demonstrator (SFD), a TTBW configuration is designated as the X-66A as shown on the left of Figure 1.  It consists of a Pratt and Whitney Geared Turbofan.  That configuration can be simulated under existing cruise conditions using existing NASA CFD tools where the propulsor can be modeled as either an actuator disk or with appropriate boundary condition at the Nacelle inlet and exhausts.  Crosswind configurations or very high angles of attack will be more difficult or not possible with those same tools.  On the right of Figure 1 is the Open Fan concept engine that GE is currently developing in their partnership with CFM International.  Having this architecture engine on the TTBW and simulating with existing NASA tools would not produce an accurate description of the interaction unless one spent months getting one unsteady result.  This capability is not only lacking at NASA, but in the industry as well.  Improved PAI simulation capability that can be done relatively quickly can allow for reduced fuel burn through modifications of the propulsor and airframe at the same time.   A blue and white airplane  Description automatically generated with low confidence A black and white spider  Description automatically generated with medium confidence   Figure 1.  On the left is the TTBW in X-66A configurationwith the turbofans with Nacelles.  On the right is the GE RISE concept OpenFan (image from CFM International).        Two NASA codes are widely used for Aircraft Simulation  FUN3D developed out of NASA Langley, and LAVA developed out of NASA Ames.  The proposed approach would be valid for both codes but would be explored with this TTT effort first using FUN3D.  The approach is to use volumetric source terms as well as the physical blockage to represent the impact of the propulsor (fan, Open Fan, or Propellor) rotor on the steady and stationary flowfield (the rotor effects are smeared out).  The physical blockage is known from the thickness distributions of the blades and their stagger angle.  The source terms would first come from current unsteady solutions and then from first-principal models that have been developed by others and can be improved by propulsion experts, AI (trained from unsteady simulations), and using test data.      Currently, FUN3D has an excellent actuator model  1  shown in Fig 2.  It allows for circumferential variations in flow quantities and is adjoint capable.  The method uses a low-speed blade element theory and does not account for the propulsor blockage.  LAVA has actuator disk capability, a volumetric source term capability but without blockage, and without production adjoint capability.           Figure 2.  Actuator Disk capability in FUN3D shown for PEGASUS concept  1 .       Rod Chima retired from NASA and had added a source term and blockage capability to his turbomachinery code, SWIFT  2 .  This code is structured multi-block, is not in active use at NASA, and was not applied to aircraft.  It was used for turbomachinery only.       The volume sources with blockage terms are outlined in a paper by Xie and Uranga  3  and the equations below come from this paper.  This method builds on work by David Hall in his MIT PhD work but added the blockage terms.  The blockage term, b, represents the blade thickness in the circumferential direction,          , and by the number of blades, B, and is defined by       and the equations of motion have the added source terms f in the momentum and energy equation       These equations are implicit in the code, APNASA, but those terms come a different model.        For this proposal, the source terms will come first from averaging (in time) the time dependent solution of an undistorted propulsor and a distorted propulsor.  The distorted propulsor will be the BLI2DTF case  4,5  that has been run experimentally and for which a Turbo  6  has been used coupled with LAVA.  Following that, the source terms will come from the models outlined in references  2,3 .  Turbo will be used to demonstrate the source terms and to implement the blockage terms since it is a simpler code than FUN3D and is used extensively for Turbomachinery simulations at NASA.      Another key aspect is that T-Blade3  7 , a turbomachinery geometry generator, will be used to define the geometry of the propulsor including the camber line, thickness and then the entire 3D turbomachinery blade.  It has been effectively used at NASA and for NASA applications since 2015. It is parametric and fully differentiated so applicable for eventual adjoint-enabled optimization.      Describe the anticipated milestones    The following work tasks are proposed.  Each task completion would be a low or higher level milestone.   Add blockage terms to Turbo by GRC Aeromechanics group   demonstration using TURBO for BLI2DTS case.  The source terms come from very careful averaging of the unsteady simulation   demonstration using TURBO with Spacefan  with and without blockage terms   Model source terms in TURBO with basic loss model and knowing geometry and rpm   use source terms (without blockage terms) with Fun3D for spacefan and compare to Turbo without blockage terms   Define the changes needed in FUN3D for blockage terms   Define geometry integration with T-Blade3 and Fun3D with loss and turning model   Outline 2nd year efforts   Each of these tasks would be done to demonstrate capability and not be done with the most rigor necessary for complete understanding.  Tasks 1 will require modifications of the TURBO source code as well as adding the source terms to Turbo.  Source terms input into FUN3D would require a small change of source code in FUN3D.       The Spacefan case is a convenient low-speed ventilation fan designed for the ISS.        Next Steps   The following tasks would be necessary after the first year    Add blockage terms to the equations of motion in FUN3D.   Demonstrate a low speed wing with a propeller with source terms   Use adjoint to modify the wing spanwise with effect of propeller   Choose a test case such as TTBW with OpenFan to demonstrate full capability.   Alternative approaches?    Since many of the steps have already been done in other contexts, the biggest risk to this approach is the aggressiveness of the schedule.  It would be focused more after a detailed assessment is done for each of the tasks.   References    Ordaz, Irian, Li Wang and Eric J. Prompt: Technical and economic trade study on using Photo-and-Photovoltaic-Batteries in Tandem with conventional or novel LH2 for long-haul (inter-continental) flights.
Description: TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS   TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE INSTRUCTIONS Please do not include your name or other contact information in this form or in the file name. Please limit the submission to 3 pages with 11 pt font or bigger. Answer the questions below. Requested resources will be addressed in the form submission and do not need to be addressed in this template. RESPOND TO PROMPTS BELOW Title  Technical and economic trade study on using Photo-and-Photovoltaic-Batteries in Tandem with conventional or novel LH2 for long-haul (inter-continental) flights. 1. Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated benefits). Address any or all of the following questions (if relevant)  What problem are you solving? Has someone tried to solve this problem before? Where did they go wrong? What is different about your approach? If no one has attempted to solve this problem before, why not? How does your proposed work transform current capabilities, tools methods or stateof-the art approaches? If successful, what does your proposed work enable that currently is unattainable? Please include references citations to back up claims where appropriate. Green aviation faces multiple challenges (technical, processing, resources, and economic). To realize this vision, the aviation industry needs to solve various parts (energy storage, propulsion, supply chain, recyclability, and safety) of the puzzle. Short-haul flights could be solved using battery technology alone, it is unlikely that long-haul or intercontinental flights would be able to run on battery technology in the foreseeable future. There are a few alternative ideas proposed in the literature such as sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), hydrogen propulsion, fuel cells, and hybrid electric vehicles, however, each of these faces its own technical, economic, and climate challenges. Any hybrid solution will require a separate battery to store energy, in addition to any backup or auxiliary systems. In such cases, the battery will occupy precious volume and mass in an aircraft. In addition, these batteries will need to be quickly recharged at an airport since other fuels require less turnaround time. This leads to two possible solutions, either fast charging at the destination or charging during the cruise portion of the flight (which is also the low-power portion of the flight). One possible solution is a photon or a photovoltaic battery, such a combined solution could reduce weight, use amble solar energy above the cloud cover, and charge the battery during flight. Note that NASA has envisioned solar cell-driven aircraft with Helios and Pathfinder in the past, but these efforts were limited to unmanned aircraft. Thus, some of the techniques and technologies can be leveraged. One of the major shortcomings of a solar cell (apart from low efficiency) is that it must be connected to a battery or other energy storage device, or a micro-grid to store distribute the electricity it generates. For this project, we propose a high-level techno-eco-sustainability study to investigate the potential benefit of combining energy storage and photovoltaics into a single integrated solution. However, a combination of these technologies is in a nascent stage with some explored integration ideas  1 , choosing a photosensitive material as an electrode or putting a PV or a battery as an integrated package (Fig. 1), for combining photovoltaics with batteries. One of the challenges is that the efficiency of a combined system is about 10 , significantly lower than a single junction (about 20   2 ), as well as current state-of-the-art multi-junction devices (the maximum efficiency is greater than 45 ). Another approach that is being developed is to use persistent phosphor for "Photon Energy-Storage". Here the photon energy is thermal energy, which can be converted through an electrochemical or a photovoltaic route. Figure 1  Different photo-charging techniques  a) closed system, b) integrated solution. The research in developing a technology can be significant and it is often necessary to develop trade-offs to venture into a new technology that is still nascent. Here we propose to perform a techno-economicenvironmental impact to understand the practicality of pursuing improving either technology while, performing the life-cycle-assessment of materials used in the technology and its environmental impact during the materials life-process (extraction, processing, reuse capability). Developing a trade study from a material, technology, recyclable, integration, supply chain, and greenness in addition to the viability of a novel technology can provide a good decision tool for new technologies. For this study, we will investigate the viability of photon-thermal electrochemical energy conversion and storage for electric aviation. a) b) The work will focus on three aspects  1) Safety, a combination of volatile electrolytes, and low melting point materials with photovoltaics could generate heat that could be catastrophic. A simple thermal analysis will be performed to identify safety risks  2) techno-economic-recyclability, using the Circular Economy Modeling and Analysis tool  3  from NREL will be used to perform technical, economic, and recyclability of technology and supply chains. Lastly, Environmental Sustainability  A comparative LCA with a cradle-to-gate approach will be performed using NREL s GREET (The Greenhouse Gases, Regulated Emissions, and Energy use in Technologies Model) software  4 . The platform evaluates the material and energy flows for battery and photovoltaic materials from raw material extraction to device production. 2. Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion. The study is divided into 3 parts and will have 3 milestones  1) weight benefits should exceed 20 , while safety should be similar or better than a hybrid system  2) techno-economic-recyclability, material availability and recyclability should be like the hybrid system  3) LCA analysis should reveal the complete life-cycle reduces carbon emissions (or carbon costs) similar to the hybrid system. 3. After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps? Where are the potential areas for transition? What follow-on research do you anticipate? If the trade-study reveals that either photon or a photo battery is beneficial to either hybrid-aircraft or future electric aviation focused airports, then the next step would be to work on identifying technology bottlenecks and solving them from a material or performance perspective. For (hypothetical) example, if photo battery was found viable for hybrid-aircraft, next step would be to focus on improving energy conversion efficiency, changing material to provide higher voltages, or charging rate of these photobatteries. Since this is a trade study, if viable it would also allow us to focus on infrastructural, material processing, device optimization, system optimization, or improving material efficiency. 4. Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation  Three months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach is not feasible technically. You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot? What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue? It is unlikely that a trade-study reveals nothing, since by nature the goal of it is to identify feasibility on various fronts. But if the project s outcome is that either photon or a photo battery is beneficial, the next step would be to focus on the technological challenge for the rest of the year. However, if it was found that neither of them would be reasonable either from an economic or safety perspective, then depending on the barrier, if it is the battery coupling, then solar cell could be explored for generating O2 and H2 for a fuel cell. However, if solar cell is found limiting, then the framework for feasibility study environmental friendly cradle-to-grave analysis for materials and process for batteries and fuelcells are developed which could be used to apply to other challenging studies. Prompt: Photovoltaics for Energy Augmentation of Electric Aircraft
Description: TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS   TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT   FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE   INSTRUCTIONS   Please do not include your name or other contact information in this form or in the file name.   Please limit the submission to 3 pages with 11 pt font or bigger.   Answer the questions below. Requested resources will be addressed in the form submission and do not need to be addressed in this template.    RESPOND TO PROMPTS BELOW   Title  Photovoltaics for Energy Augmentation of Electric Aircraft   Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated benefits).  Address any or all of the following questions (if relevant)  What problem are you solving?  Has someone tried to solve this problem before?  Where did they go wrong?  What is different about your approach?  If no one has attempted to solve this problem before, why not?  How does your proposed work transform current capabilities, tools methods or state-of-the art approaches?  If successful, what does your proposed work enable that currently is unattainable? Please include references citations to back up claims where appropriate.       Climate change is the greatest threat to humanity.  We are in a race to develop solutions that maintain and improve quality of life without intensifying causes of climate change.  The development of electrified aircraft allows humanity to maintain civilization with less carbon emissions. One challenge to electrification of aircraft is the mass of batteries required to sustain flight significantly limits the aircraft payload and flight duration.  We propose the inclusion of high voltage, thin film, perovskite based solar arrays laminated onto the aircraft wings and fuselage in production. The integration of these solar cells offset power density needs for batteries for electrified aircraft reducing weight. When coupled with a fuselage manufactured from light weight next generation materials.       Outfitting an electric airplane with perovskite solar cells would offset power density needs for the Lithium ion batteries, reducing weight.  If we assume a 737 airplane traveling from NYC to LA on a sunny day, with modest 20  efficient perovskite solar cells integrated, the solar cells would generate 320 kWhr of energy on that flight. This is achieved with just 1.2 kg of perovskite solar cells total mass over the plane. That energy allows a mass reduction of 1200 kg of lithium ion batteries. These ultralight weight solar cells save 1200 kg of battery mass. Perovskites are especially propitious for photovoltaic application due to their exceptional properties, such as large-charge carrier diffusion lengths  1 , long carrier lifetimes, strong optical absorption  2 , weak exciton binding  3 , and favorable band gaps  2 . Perovskite based photovoltaics are thin films (300-500 nm) light weight, low cost, and are compatible with solution or vapor phase processing techniques. Multi-junction (tandem) solar cells consisting of multiple light absorbers with considerably different bandgaps show great potential in breaking the theoretical efficiency limit of a single junction solar cell (33 ) by absorbing light in a broader range of wavelengths. 4  These tandem solar cells are expected to achieve power conversion efficiencies up to 25.2  (with theoretical limits of 42 ) and are 500X thinner than the current state of the art (SOA) technology.  Perovskite solar cells also absorb light more strongly than SOA GaAs solar cells.      My previous research has led to the development of single junction perovskite solar cell at reproducible 20  power conversion efficiency that can withstand the harsh low earth environment and are stable to terrestrial stressors. We can apply lessons learned from that effort to develop a lightweight low-cost perovskite based tandem photovoltaic capable of greater power output. We will select materials suitable for the wide bandgap (1.7-1.9 eV) second junction solar cell and we will demonstrate the ability to fabricate these cells, regardless of solvent compatibility, with a lamination technique that has been demonstrated to be effective with perovskite interlayers. 5        Electrified aircraft is a newer venture with the first passenger electric aircraft, Alice, flight in September 2022.  Long duration unmanned air vehicles augmented with photovoltaics like the AeroVironment Helios vehicle have demonstrated feasibility of solar and fuel cell powered aerial vehicles.  These vehicles have currently been limited to small payload vehicles as mass is limited.  Emerging photovoltaic technologies, like those based on perovskites, allow for previously unachievable specific powers (W kg).  When compared to the state of the art III-V or Silicon solar cells, perovskites       Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion.   MS1  Demonstration of lamination of single junction perovskite solar cell with heat press showing the feasibility of the process to combine two junctions together to form a tandem cell.   MS2  Material down selection for wide bandgap second junction active layer material with special considerations for efficiency, durability, and manufacturability.    MS3  Model the electrical performance of the second junction solar cell with primary candidate material.   MS4  Deposit and characterize the optical and electrical performance of the wide bandgap perovskite material.    This work should be evaluated on the delivery of materials identified and selected for the second junction wide bandgap perovskite solar cell.  This work should also be evaluated on the computational predicted performance of the resulting tandem device. The proposed tandem device efficiency, manufacturability, and durability should be considered.    After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps?  Where are the potential areas for transition?  What follow-on research do you anticipate?    The next steps of this research should include deposition of the champion wide bandgap perovskite active layer for the second junction. We will then use the lamination technique to combine the first and second junction of the devices to yield a tandem perovskite based photovoltaic. We will perform local optimization to increase the power conversion efficiency and test the cell in relevant environmental stressors including humidity and thermal stresses.   This work has applications in both the terrestrial and space markets. Potential transition to TACP or GCD can facilitate further technical development and advancement of technology readiness level.  There are also many small businesses and universities in this area so SBIR STTR opportunities could facilitate tech transfer and commercialization.     Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation   Three months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach is not feasible technically.  You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot?  What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue?    If, three months into this work, I discovered that our lamination technique was not feasible for the materials I selected, I would first revisit where in the stack I was laminating. There may be a different material layer more suited to undergo this process.  If that did not resolve the technical challenges I would revisit materials selection, guided by literature, and alter my deposition technique either to omit the need for lamination or to ensure compatibility. We will use a combination of the literature, evidence-based decision making, computational modeling, and experimental materials development to design a wide bandgap perovskite photovoltaic that will supplement the absorption of existing perovskite solar cell providing a path toward energy augmentation for electrified aircraft.        1  L. Prompt: Hydrogen Powered Aviation Through Sustainable Manufacturing and Repair of Carbon Fiber Reinforced Thermoplastic Composite Cryotanks.
Description: Title  Hydrogen Powered Aviation Through Sustainable Manufacturing and Repair of Carbon Fiber Reinforced Thermoplastic Composite Cryotanks. 1. Provide a description of the work  The current use of fossil fuels within the aviation industry contributes more to global warming than is generally appreciated because of the mix of climate pollutants it generates. A recent model analyzed the CO2 and non-CO2 effects (like nitrogen oxide emissions and contrail formation) to assess aviation's total warming footprint. The report found aviation contributed approximately 4  to observed human-induced global warming to date, despite being responsible for only 2.4  of global annual emissions of CO2.(1) One solution to the continued impact of aviation on climate change is a shift toward Sustainable Aviation Fuels (SAFs), such as hydrogen. The European Clean Aviation Initiative reports that hydrogen power can be part of the green aviation solution in that hydrogen power completely eliminates CO2 emissions and can be produced carbon-free. Considering non-CO2 emissions as well, the latest estimates show that hydrogen combustion could reduce the climate impact of flight by up to 75 , and fuel-cell propulsion by up to 90 .(2) The Clean Sky 2 Program, which is part of the Clean Aviation Initiative found that hydrogen either for fuel cells, direct burn in gas turbine engines or as a building block for synthetic liquid fuels could feasibly power aircraft with entry into service by 2035 for shortrange aircraft at a cost of less than  20 extra per person on a short-range flight, and reducing climate impact by 50 to 90 . (3) Problem  While a clear pay-off exists for hydrogen powered aircraft, the physical space required to carry gaseous hydrogen is large, requiring cryogenic storage hydrogen fuel as a liquid, at -253oC. The successful utilization of lightweight carbon fiber polymer composite tanks has met challenges cycling to this temperature, the primary challenge being microcracking of the matrix. Has someone tried to solve the problem before. Composite cryotanks have been evaluated by industry and Government for decades.(4) The most common materials and manufacturing approach for composite tanks has been autoclave consolidated carbon fiber and epoxy composite. As the tank is subjected to repeated fill drain cycles, the mismatch in the coefficient of thermal expansion between the carbon fiber reinforcement and epoxy matrix leads to residual stresses in the laminated tank wall resulting in matrix microcracking (5). This was addressed by the NASA Composite Cryotank Technology Demonstration Project in 2013 by using thin plies to reduce interlaminar stresses. This approach was successful in reducing, but not eliminating microcracking. Once microcracking starts, it cannot be repaired in an epoxy matrix cryotank. In addition, the epoxy matrix material is cured in an autoclave which is a high energy process and requires the use of non-recyclable  non-reusable consumable materials. A separate materials option for composite cryotanks is carbon fiber reinforced thermoplastics. Thermoplastic matrix composites offer greater compliance than the traditional epoxy (thermoset) matrix materials and therefore the potential to reduce matrix microcracking. There has been limited research using thermoplastics due to manufacturing challenges such as low drapability of the composite prepreg and the requirement for high processing temperatures. Recent developments in low melt temperature materials and automated manufacturing provide new opportunities for this material class. Thermoplastic composites are receiving attention for cryogen storage, most notably a study is currently underway in the Netherlands to build and evaluate thermoset and thermoplastics composites for liquid hydrogen cryotanks for commercial aircraft. (6) Where did they go wrong what is different about this approach  We propose to focus on thermoplastics, and pushing a step further than the European study we propose to experimentally and analytically evaluate thermoplastic composites for (a) viability as a composite cryo-tank material for hydrogen, (b) repairability of microcracking within the matrix to increase the lifetime and reduce waste and (c) reduce the cost and environmental impact of manufacturing relative to the state-of-the-art autoclave consolidation through use of thermoplastic welding options, such as ultrasonic welding. If successful the proposed work will enable hydrogen-based propulsion opportunities within the aviation industry, energy savings in manufacturing, and increased safety through repairability of the thermoplastic tank. 2. Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion. The key performance requirement for a composite cryo-tank is that it holds cryogenic liquid. Microcracking has been identified as the primary path for cryogen loss through the tank wall, therefore the feasibility of microcrack mitigation and repair will be the focus of this initial effort. a. State-of-the-Art (SOA) assessment and partner identification. The past 3-5 years have seen a resurgence of U.S. based research with thermoplastic matrix composites leading to rapid advances in manufacturing and materials testing. i. A SOA assessment will be used to establish baseline metrics for consolidation quality for composites manufactured out of the autoclave and repaired composites. ii. A partner will be identified for ultrasonic welding of thermoplastic composites. NASA GRC has current contracts for thermoplastic welding with Agile Ultrasonics in Columbus Ohio. This is for flat coupon welds, (as opposed to a tank) iii. Feasibility assessment will be performed to  trade  thermoset and thermoplastic composite materials through analysis. Existing database properties will be used. b. Assess feasibility of sustainable (out-of-autoclave) manufacturing  build upon NASA s recent experience with thermoplastic welding to demonstrate out-of autoclave consolidation of flat panels and plates. i. Establish industry partnership for out-of-autoclave manufacturing via ultrasonic welding methods. - Manufacture flat panels to generate test coupons for compression strength and interlaminar shear strength. - Manufacture cylindrical components to demonstrate manufacturing at the subcomponent level. - Finite element analysis to for failure prediction. - Evaluate consolidation quality through standard inspection techniques and baseline mechanical tests. ii. Establish in-house capability for ultrasonic welding. - Manufacture flat panels to generate compression and interlaminar shear strength test coupons for comparison to industry fabricated parts. - Manufacture cylindrical components to demonstrate manufacturing at the subcomponent level. - Evaluate consolidation quality through standard inspection techniques and baseline mechanical tests. - Data comparison between in-house and industry manufactured parts will be used to inform in-house process development. c. Assess feasibility of microcrack repair  utilize established welding techniques to re-melt heal microcracks in the composite matrix. i. Induce microcracking in the thermoplastic composite through cycling to cryogenic temperature. ii. Repair the cracks through ultrasonic welding methods. iii. Mechanical testing of repaired coupons for comparison to pristine d. Budget  Costs for this project are associated with materials, manufacturing, and test. This includes a contract for ultrasonic welding (out of autoclave consolidation) while concurrently building the capability in-house. 3. After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps? This work will establish feasibility of the material class to enable sustainable aviation through reduced energy manufacturing and a transition to hydrogen fuel. Next steps include but are not limited to the following. a. Establish a team with expertise in the requirements of hydrogen powered aviation to define requirements of the composite tank and support structure. b. Establish a team to design the tank and support structure including connections, fittings, baffles slosh mitigation, fuel lines, etc. c. Establish a design and analysis team to ensure margins of safety are met for the cryo-tank. d. Develop analysis tools to predict microcracking based on micromechanics models. e. Follow the building block approach to manufacture and test from the coupon to the component level. Potential area of transition includes the Commercially Viable Hydrogen Aircraft for Reduction of Greenhouse Emissions Project. 4. Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation  Three months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach is not feasible technically. You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot? What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue? a. For this effort there are multiple paths to address this scenarioi. We have proposed two technology developments, lightweight composite tank, and energy savings through out of autoclave manufacturing. The energy savings in manufacturing is the higher risk component of this proposal due to challenges in meeting the consolidation quality achieved in an autoclave. If deemed technically infeasible we can focus on the composite tank in a traditional manufacturing environment. ii. Second option would be to shift the focus away from tanks and move to more energy efficient manufacturing for aircraft structures. This is work we had started through CIF funding and can continue. Prompt: Robust Repair and Refurbishment Technologies Enabling Reusability and Life Extension of Ceramic Matrix Composites Propulsion Components
Description: TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS   TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT   FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE   Title   Robust Repair and Refurbishment Technologies Enabling Reusability and Life Extension of Ceramic Matrix Composites Propulsion Components    Advanced silicon carbide fiber reinforced silicon carbide matrix (SiC SiC) composite components are currently in service and being further developed for insertion in several turbine engine applications. The advantages of ceramic matrix composites (CMCs) over metals include lower weight, higher temperature capability and stability, and corrosion resistance while the advantages over monolithic (non-fiber reinforced) ceramics include damage tolerance, graceful failure, and thermal shock resistance. CMC turbine engine components offer significant performance benefits of reduced cooling, fuel burn, and emissions (NOx and COx), however, the materials are relatively expensive with complex manufacturing required for the integrated constituents of the CMC. During service, the CMC components (e.g. turbine blades, vanes, shrouds, and combustor liners) experience degradation in performance due to various forms of damage including oxidation, impact damage, erosion, surface spallation, and delamination. Currently, as CMC parts wear out and, in some cases, when cooling channels within CMCs are degraded or clogged, they need to be replaced with brand new parts. The continuous replacement of CMC components will be quite expensive given the high acquisition cost of components. It will also contribute to material waste and a higher demand for labor, time, and energy resources during their fabrication compared to that of refurbished parts.    Currently, metallic turbine engine components are regularly repaired and refurbished during engine overhauls to extend life of components. This repair and refurbishment provide significant cost savings, extends reliability, safety, and life of components as well as reduce wastes. However, looking at the ceramic matrix composite landscape, no viable repair or refurbishment technology is available. At GRC, we have significant experience in developing repair and refurbishment technologies for space shuttle leading edges (C C composites) and a collaborative program with Goodrich Corp. for the C C composite aircraft brake repair and refurbishment.  These technologies were developed at high TRL level and wide variety of testing was conducted.    We propose to advance the state-of-the-art by developing methods to repair and refurbish SiC SiC CMCs to retain material performance requirements and extend their service life thus reducing waste. As of now, there are no suitable methods to extend the life of damaged CMCs using repair and refurbishment technologies. One method investigated by other researchers is the self-healing of cracked CMCs by forming glasses in the matrix or coating which melt and flow to fill in cracks (ref. 1-2). However, the formed glass can only slowdown the oxidation in the vicinity of a matrix crack without contributing to CMC mechanical load carrying capability. Also, low melting glasses are not appropriate as they create stress corrosion, vaporization, and reduce service life. Currently used CMCs do not have any glass forming constituents due to these reasons. Any repair and refurbishment technology should not only be able to repair only cracks but other forms of CMC damage such as cooling channels restoration. It should also avoid potential chemical incompatibility with the CMCs and or their environmental barrier coatings (EBCs). Furthermore, the self-healing crack methods have temperature capabilities well below the SiC SiC maximum service temperature of 2400 F and especially the new target of 2700 F for next generation SiC SiC. A group from Boeing has investigated patches for repairing space shuttle leading edges (ref. 3). Their approach does not seem to have been fully developed or reported. The leading-edge patches are not fully processed until earth-atmosphere-reentry heating where the high reentry temperatures act to pyrolyze the material. At NASA GRC, Dr. Mrityunjay Singh, who is part of this proposal, had developed  Glenn Refractory Adhesive for Bonding and Exterior Repair (GRABER) (refs. 4-8) , which was successfully used for repairing reinforced carbon carbon composite (RCC) with different types of damage (cracks, spallation, delamination, etc). The verification and qualification testing was carried out in arc-jet testing facilities at NASA JSC, NASA Ames, and Boeing LCAT facilities in St. Louis, MO. He has also worked with largest US aircraft brake manufacturer for the repair and refurbishment of C C composite aircraft brakes. Experience gained from the assessment of CMC damage and repair techniques will be leveraged for our specific case of SiC SiC CMCs for turbine engine applications with an emphasis on retaining mechanical properties and environmental stability in a steam environment. Engine combustion environments are rich in water vapor which can cause reactions and surface recession and degradation of SiC SiC materials.    The approach is to develop a method for the repair and refurbishment of SiC SiC CMCs. Material compositions will be developed and evaluated. Processing conditions will be optimized. Various types of flaws (e.g. surface, through holes, and de-laminations) will be introduced into the CMC test specimens. For larger flaws, a preform of SiC woven cloth will be integrated with the repair materials for maintaining CMC structural integrity. The ability for the repair and patch methods to retain mechanical strength and environmental durability will be assessed. Testing of tensile coupons while under a mechanical stress in a steam environment will be conducted to compare the performance of undamaged, damaged   unrepaired, and damaged   repaired CMCs. The results will be analyzed to determine repair effectiveness. Correlations will be made between material microstructures, processing conditions, and properties.    CMC materials and lab equipment are available for the activity. Mechanical testing will be conducted in load frames with the ability to test in various environments such as oxidizing and steam. Strain will be monitored by high temperature extensometers and digital image correlation. Damage will be monitored and assessed using acoustic emission technique which will help determine conditions for inducing damage in samples prior to applying the repair technology. The well-equipped labs and relevant experience in ceramic processing, repair, mechanical testing, and environmental exposure provides a good chance for success, rapid progress, and requires no new capabilities.    CMCs enable more efficient turbine engines for reducing fuel consumption, carbon emissions and environmental impacts due to their higher operating temperatures, reduced cooling requirements, and improved engine efficiency. Successful repair methods will further enhance the green technology benefits of CMCs by contributing to their greater utilization in turbine engines, longer component lives, and reduced costs and waste.   Milestones   Identify relevant types of SiC SiC CMC damage, suitable repair materials, and processing approaches (12 2023).   Develop compositions and processing conditions for repair materials to be applied to damaged SiC SiC coupons (3 2024).    Develop a silicon carbide fiber reinforced patch repair method for larger flaws (6 2024).   Evaluate repaired and unrepaired composites under relevant mechanical stresses and environmental conditions (9 2024).     The work will be evaluated based on the ability to retain the mechanical properties and environmental durability in the repaired CMC compared to the performance of the unrepaired CMC. Success will be achieved if there is significant improvement in the usability of the repaired CMC. Monotonic tensile tests will be performed at room or high temperature on repaired and unrepaired CMCs to quantify the enhancement in strength provided by CMC repair technology. Additionally, stress rupture testing of repaired and non-repaired CMC test coupons in a steam rig under a constant or cyclic load until failure will be conducted. Next, the times to failure will be compared for as-fabricated, repaired, and non-repaired SiC SiC tensile specimens to identify the improvement in CMC life and reusability provided by the implemented CMC repair technology.   If the repair of SiC SiC activity is successful, the next steps are to further increase the technology readiness level (TRL). Composite repair could be progressed toward an actual SiC SiC turbine engine component. Repair of a complex geometry could be addressed as well as integrating the reapplication or repair of an EBC coating. For patch repairs with woven SiC cloth, fiber coatings can be integrated for enhanced mechanical properties. Also, for repairs over CMC components with film cooling holes, the reintroduction of cooling holes can be demonstrated.    The CMC repair technology can be transferred to engine companies. Also, there are transition opportunities for ground-based power generation. There may be opportunities to collaborate with NASA aeronautics projects or engine companies which are testing or are already using CMC components. The repair of their tested and in-service parts could be demonstrated.    With our past experiences and lab capabilities, we stand a good chance of developing SiC SiC CMC repair technology and believe we have made a fair assessment of the feasibility. However, if the method was determined to be non-feasible, we could quickly pivot our activities. If there was an issue with material or processing compatibility, we could adjust our approach to be better matched with SiC SiC materials. If the whole approach is not feasible and needs to be abandoned, we would pursue another necessary and relevant technology for CMCs. During the remaining months, joining and integration technologies could be pursued which allow for the buildup of larger and more complex shaped CMC parts as well as their incorporation with metal-based systems (e.g. support structures, blade roots and hubs, cooling manifolds, etc.). Our team has extensive experience in developing joining and integration technologies which can be leveraged here. Each joining approach must be tailored for its specific case based on material pairings (e.g. CMC to CMC or CMC to metal), joining interlayer approach (e.g. paste, foil, hybrid, and multi-layer), joining method (e.g. brazing, diffusion bonding, eutectic phase bonding, reactive slurry infiltration), part geometries, applications conditions (e.g. operating environment, temperature, and stress) and performance requirements. A narrowed focus could be to demonstrate the feasibility of a brazing approach for the case of brazing a SiC SiC CMC blade root to a metallic rotor hub.    References   1.  Rebillat, F. "Advances in self-healing ceramic matrix composites." In Advances in ceramic matrix composites, pp. 475-514. Woodhead Publishing, 2014.   2. Patches for Repairing Ceramics and Ceramic-Matrix Composites. No. MSC-24018. 2006.   4. M. Prompt: Performance Enhancement of Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cell Components with Machine Learning for Electric Aircraft Propulsion
Description: TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS   TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT   FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE   Title  Performance Enhancement of Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cell Components with Machine Learning for Electric Aircraft Propulsion   Description of the work    NASA aeronautics goals include pioneering new technology to reduce emissions, noise, and carbon footprint from air travel.  The feasibility of using fuel cells and on-board cryogenic hydrogen (H2) systems in combination with electric motors for zero emission commercial transport aircraft has been widely examined.  Developing a practical, implementable carbon-free electric power system for a highly constrained  electric aircraft  application is a complex and complicated poly-dimensional optimization problem. The primary factor limiting fuel cell implementation remains thermal management at the required high fuel cell stack specific power levels resulting from inadequate heat transfer and unacceptably inefficient operation manifesting as low average cell voltage (Vcc). Despite many historical and current research efforts by government, academia, and aviation industry, the relative importance of design parameters across multiple systems and levels of assembly remains poorly understood.  Materials science and engineering has played a central role in the evolution of improved electrochemical technologies such as fuel cells and batteries. However, traditional   Edisonian   approaches to evolve from discovery to commercial implementation is too costly and time consuming relative to the accelerating anthropogenic climate change resulting from Carbon Cycle disruptions. The emergence of Machine Learning (ML) modeling methods with increasingly powerful computers has augmented cross-disciplinary technological advances from materials discovery to commercialized products.  This activity proposes using the latest artificial intelligence (AI) research to develop two ML models. the first model is critical to understand the relationships among system-level variables for electric aircraft propulsion (EAP) by assessing fuel cell power system response (Vcc) to the normalized aircraft electrical load current density (i) (          (          ,  ,                     ,       .)                              ,    ,                                 ,            .   ). The second model will implement a self-driven approach based on the first model and leverage existing models to elucidate the critical supporting parameters for optimizing the fuel cell system operation and calculate the EAP fuel cell power system performance metrics of power density (W L), specific power (W kg) and long-term stability (                        ) from repeated experimentation.  Establishing a self-driving laboratory for a ML fuel cell technology modeling tool marks a pioneering leap in sustainable energy research which sets it apart from traditional modeling methodologies like Monte Carlo modeling. This information will focus objective development goals by identifying material, components and or system interfaces that can viably meet EAP performance metrics and provide feasible performance profiles for aircraft-level models investigating EAP. These sensitive parameters potentially can range from fuel cell component materials, mechanisms to enhance convective heat transfer, to low mass phase change materials, to optimizing power management and distribution (PMAD) components for reducing ohmic resistance. The study is a general development of a tool of FC for implementing EAP in the medium-scale commercial aircraft as it provides the most impactful transformation to zero emission commercial aviation.   References   Abolhasani, M., Montoya, J.,   Fathabadi, H. (2019). Industry 4.0 applications in energy systems  A comprehensive review. Energy Reports, 5, 1349-1377.   Zhou, Z.  Zholobko, O., et alia, Polybenzimidazole-Based Polymer Electrolyte Membranes for High-Temperature Fuel Cells  Current Status and Prospects. Energies 2021, 14, 135.   Qu, E.  Hao, X et alia  Proton exchange membranes for high temperature proton exchange membrane fuel cells  Challenges and perspectives. Journal of Power Sources 2022, 533, 231386   High Temperature Polymer Electrolyte Membrane Fuel Cells Approaches, Status, and Perspectives, edited by Li, Q.  Aili, D.  Hjuler, H.A.  Jensen, J.O., 2016, Springer International Pub., Switzerland   Anticipated milestones and Performance Metrics   Figure 1 illustrates the proposed iterative project workflow required to develop and train the ML model within the self-driving laboratory and conduct the statistical data evaluation for producing feasible and actionable data products of system sensitivity parameters influencing cell voltage response (Vcc) to the power demanded by the aircraft when assessed in electrical current density (i in mA cm2). The five-(5) project milestones are shown in a GANTT chart in Figure 2.   Figure 1  Schematic of Project Work Plan   The work starts with collecting relevant PEM FC performance data, especially those for vehicle and aircraft propulsion, to develop the ML training data sets. Where the statistical evaluation determines that data gaps exist, synthetic data will be generated based on first-principal models. In parallel, the first ML tool element will develop a precise machine learning model that can predict the voltage response of the fuel cell system to the vehicle electrical load demand. Through preliminary statistical work, model building, and feature engineering, this first element will provide valuable insights into system variables and the relative relationship among these variables. While Monte Carlo models are valuable for probabilistic analysis and estimating outcomes within well-defined distributions, self-driving AI ML labs offer a superior approach. The most influential ML tool element will drive NASA software in a self-driven lab for closing any gaps between the fuel cell system performance metrics and aircraft performance requirements. These labs are equipped to autonomously conduct experiments, adapt to changing conditions, and continuously learn from data. By harnessing machine learning and AI, they minimize the potential for errors and inefficiencies associated with human intervention. This innovative approach aligns with the vision of Industry 4.0, where the integration of cutting-edge technologies reshapes manufacturing and research processes (Abolhasani et al., 2019). Furthermore, the self-driving lab seamlessly integrates with our software to drive tools toward achievable desired outputs. This symbiotic relationship enhances fuel cell performance, ultimately advancing the frontiers of sustainable energy research and development. Any deficiencies in the resulting specific power, power density, and performance stability then guide development objectives to improve FC power and propulsion system performance.    This effort will produce six-(6) deliverables  a preliminary EAP requirements set, a ML modeling tool consisting of two elements, a preliminary PEM fuel cell model performance set, Data Gap Closure Resource Estimate, a ML model Validation Resource Estimate, and a final report.           Figure 2  Project GANTT Chart   Follow-on Activities   The products of this foundational work would be integrated into existing aircraft-level models for developing electric aircraft and accelerate the development of the FC power and propulsion systems. Learning more about the relationships between system variables (features or input) will focus future research on the technologies limiting this application. In the next phase of this work, a significant experimental data collection is anticipated in order to replace the synthetic data by empirical data to validate and improve the ML model fidelity. Should these products become sufficiently mature, it remains feasible to incorporated them into an eventual Digital Twin model architecture.    PI Scenario   This scenario does not apply to this process as ML modeling is inherently an iterative process that utilizes the  fail early, fail often, but always fail forward  (J.C. Maxwell) approach. The ML model matures with each iteration and provides valuable insights into the poly-dimensional space under investigation. There exist multiple tools that can be used should one fail and there exists a great deal of data to mine that could be temporarily supported by synthetic data until credible empirical data became available. Implementing FC power and propulsion systems in a carbon-free electric aircraft includes many challenges available for ML modeling. There are many components, sub-systems, and interfaces that require additional performance data and development prior to integrating into an electric aircraft. Should resources become available, conducting experiments to close any identified data gaps would improve data quality.

Prompt: Maximizing the Efficiency of Advanced Air Mobility with Formation Flight
Description: TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS   TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT   FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL   INSTRUCTIONS   Please do not include your name or other contact information in this form or in the file name.   Please limit the submission to 3 pages with 11 pt font or bigger.   Answer the questions below. Requested resources will be addressed in the form submission and do not need to be addressed in this template.    RESPOND TO PROMPTS BELOW   Title  Maximizing the Efficiency of Advanced Air Mobility with Formation Flight   Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated benefits).  Address any or all of the following questions (if relevant)  What problem are you solving?  Has someone tried to solve this problem before?  Where did they go wrong?
