What is different about your approach?  If no one has attempted to solve this problem before, why not?  How does your proposed work transform current capabilities, tools methods or state-of-the art approaches?  If successful, what does your proposed work enable that currently is unattainable? Please include references citations to back up claims where appropriate.       Formation flying is a well-known approach for improving the efficiency of flight. Migratory birds flying in V-formation gain significant efficiency by taking advantage of the upwash from the wing tip of the leading bird, which allows the trailing birds to fly with reduced angle-of-attack and lower induced drag  1 . For birds and aircraft alike, the key to gaining maximum efficiency with this technique is identifying the optimal configuration of the formation. While birds can do this adaptively in actual flight (and millions of years of evolution), computational tools are needed to investigate the possible benefits for safely improving the efficiency of human air transportation especially for use of newly emerging electric-Vertical Takeoff and Landing (eVTOL) vehicle designs.   The computational objectives needed for a comprehensive study of formation flight are    Finding the optimal formation configuration as function of vehicle types design and flight conditions,   Identifying the most efficient (and safe) way to form the configuration,   and maneuver within the formation, e.g., to transfer the lead-aircraft   potentially with specialized actuators for control within the wake where traditional actuators (e.g., ailerons) lose effectiveness.   A study of the control laws to   automatically hold the optimal configuration,   while remaining robust to adverse weather disturbances,   Determining methods to maneuver the overall formation as one,    and compute optimal trajectories of the formation in weather.      The concept of formation flight is not new and has been studied extensively. Some theoretical studies have shown potential drag reduction for extended formation flight at 38 -45 , and flight tests with more conventional vehicle types (F A 18 and C-17) at AFRC have shown fuel flow reduction of 7 -18   2 .  Flight dynamics in wake is not necessarily LTI (linear time invariant) but is nonlinear LTV (linear time varying)  3 .  The efficiency gains from free lift associated with formation flight may be offset by degradation in stability and control.  Safety and ride quality are important considerations.  The uncertainty around the trade-space for eVTOL vehicles is exactly why this type of work needs to be funded initially at a small funding level.  Because of the nature of the challenges in many different areas (nonlinear aerodynamics, nonlinear LTV flight dynamics, and nonlinear control), this is a rich area for research.  There are computational models for wake interaction currently under development  4  which could be utilized in this study to enable rapid assessment and trade-space exploration.      There are however few (if any) studies on optimization of formation flight for more efficient Urban Air Mobility operations with eVTOL vehicles. Also, the simultaneous considerations of control robustness and formation safety are missing from all the studies that we know of. Traditionally, flight safety is concerned with wake avoidance, whereas the objective here is to leverage it for energy savings.        1  J. C. Chan, P. C. Wang, and H. Hesse. Aerodynamic interactions in formation flight for wake vortex surfing. In AIAA AVIATION 2023 Forum, 2023.    2  J. Pahle, D. Berger, M. Venti, C. Duggan, J. Faber, and K. Cardinal. An initial flight investigation of formation flight for drag reduction on the c-17 aircraft. In AIAA Atmospheric Flight Mechanics Conference, 2012.    3  J. E. Bacui, N. Nguyen, W. Okolo and J. Xiong. Wake Vortex Effects Between Urban Air Mobility Aircraft, AIAA Atmospheric Flight Mechanics Conference, AIAA-2023-1558, January 2023.    4  N. Nguyen. A Physics-Based Spatial Wake Interactional Model of Fixed-Wing Aircraft and Rotorcraft for Urban Air Mobility.  In AIAA SciTech Forum, 19-21 January 2021.      Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion.   In the seedling effort, a sandbox demonstration case will be developed for a formation of three UAM Lift Cruise reference design vehicles (already available from collaborative work with the RVLT project). The problem will be analyzed computationally to determine optimal vehicle configuration (distance and orientation of vehicles to each-other) in a cruise flight-condition for maximum range given a total energy constraint. Initial models for the formation in the cruise condition (with additional states for aerodynamic interactions) will be developed and analyzed from a robust control perspective to gauge the feasibility for safe operations with adverse weather (simulated using a gust and Dryden turbulence models). The final results are intended to inform the creation of new formation flight-based sustainability technical challenges within TTT.   Schematic of the NASA Lift Cruise reference vehicle concept ...   Figure 1  RVLT Lift Cruise Concept Design   After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps?  Where are the potential areas for transition?  What follow-on research do you anticipate?    Analyzing the overall safety of formation flight and, especially, convincing the FAA, will be the most difficult part. Further investigation will be required into vehicle technologies for detecting failures in advance and the ability to break formation safely when adverse events occur. Developing the computational technology (and leveraging existing solutions) required to address all of the aforementioned objectives could form the basis for a new technical challenge within the TTT project, one that simultaneously explores the aerodynamics, vehicle design, and robust fault-tolerant control required to realize the full benefit of formation flight for sustainable aviation.      Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation   Three months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach is not feasible technically.  You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot?  What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue?    If initial results show insufficient benefit, pivoting to consideration of vehicle design for increasing the benefit of formation flight is a possibility. This might include the design of wing-tip modifications, use of variable camber flaps, or even the optimized design of a specialized unmanned lead vehicle that allows passenger carrying vehicles to fly behind it with maximized efficiency.

Prompt: Sensor System Study for Health Management of Sustainable Aviation Based on Electric Propulsion
Description: TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS   TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL Title  Sensor System Study for Health Management of Sustainable Aviation Based on Electric Propulsion 1. Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated benefits). Problem  NASA is committed to supporting the U.S. climate goal of achieving net-zero greenhouse gas emissions from the aviation sector by 2050 and is leading federal agencies and industry to accelerate the development of sustainable aviation technologies. This includes developing and deploying alternate, new vehicle designs and architectures including Hybrid Electric or All Electric vehicle concepts  1,2 . Examples are the Subsonic Single Aft Engine (SUSAN) Electrofan, the Singleaisle Turboelectric AiRCraft with Aft Boundary Layer propulsor (STARC-ABL), and other activities  3,4,5 . However, these aircraft concepts introduce new hardware systems along with new health management challenges. For example, fault detection and diagnostics of hybrid electric or all electric propulsion systems requires an understanding of the operation, performance, degradation, and failure mechanisms of electric machines, converters (inverters rectifiers), and power cables along with the operation of these devices in increasingly complex flight environments  6 . Introduction of new vehicle types and integrated power and propulsion systems requires increasingly intelligent vehicle systems with capability to detect, diagnose, and predict system degradation, faults, and failures in a resilient and trustworthy manner. Furthermore, intelligent vehicle systems must be capable of estimating system capability as it degrades. Monitoring the system health state has an impact on system operating cost, performance, efficiency, and environmental impact. Predictive maintenance reduces maintenance cost and vehicle down-time through reduced unnecessary maintenance costs and improved vehicle availability and throughput. Efforts are ongoing to evaluate and document potential failure modes and hazards posed by an Electrified Aircraft Propulsion (EAP) system  6 . Due to their increased complexity and integrated nature, EAP systems present additional failure modes and hazards not found in conventional aircraft propulsion designs. Mitigation of these EAP failures requires a system-level design and analysis approach, which is on-going. Major findings of this work include that EAP degradation, faults, and failure modes present new health management challenges. This requires background understanding of electrical engineering and system control and concept of operations (motor control, generator control, battery management systems). Furthermore, electrical systems don t always degrade fail gracefully, which makes early (timely) diagnosis to enable maintenance challenging. Faults include those associated with  electric machines (motors generators) such as the health of bearings, lubrication and cooling, windings, rotor, insulation  converters (inverters rectifiers), electronic components and the cooling system  high voltage wire and cables, including short or open circuits and insulation breakdown  overall power quality including degradation faults leading to voltage ripple and power instabilities  and thermal management system and battery failures (thermal runaway). These types of faults require new sensor measurement types compared to turbine engine, e.g., concentrating on current and voltage, and tailored for a new infrastructure associated with EAP rather than turbine engines. Although these faults are being identified in  System Analysis and Failure mode, effects, and criticality analysis (FEMCA) studies presently ongoing in the ARMD  7 , there is limited ongoing work related to understanding the sensor types and sensing approaches most optimized for this new aircraft infrastructure. Such an understanding is a necessary first step toward Integrated Vehicle Health Management (IVHM), combining sensing, diagnostics, and prognostics, for future Sustainable Aviation based on EAP. Objectives  This task will work in parallel with the ongoing analysis of EAP fault detection  6,7  to examine sensors and sensor systems that can address fault detection in EAP aircraft. The challenges for sensor technology for EAP applications include  operation in a high noise environment or with corona discharge at altitude  increasing integration of sensor technology into electric components to minimize size weight power and cost  multi parameter measurements to better understand the health state of the EAP system  providing actionable information for higher level diagnostics  and leveraging the EAP architecture itself to provide better system level diagnostics. This task intends to formulate a framework for sensor and sensors systems for EAP health management applications addressing these challenges. Approach  In particular, this task will examine the EAP architecture and fault studies to first understand the wide range of potential failure mechanisms. It will then survey the existing methods of EAP fault detection to both understand how it is done now, and shortfalls to these approaches. It will then examine methods for improved EAP sensing including, e.g., new sensor types or additive manufacturing. The conclusion of this work is a white paper summarizing the above activities and a preliminary road map for possible ARMD future investment in this area. This task leverages the ongoing activities in the Intelligent Control and Autonomy Branch (LCC) and related existing expertise and capabilities  7 . Coordination between multiple sensor Subject Matter Experts (SME) within the Communications and Intelligent Systems Division, as well as SME in other Branches both at NASA Glenn Research Center and across the agency is planned. At least one trip is planned given available resources to a relevant conference related to this topic and or industry to broaden the input provided to this study. Although not presently proposed, but could considered with project management, is the possibility of hosting a Technical Interchange Meeting (TIM) on the topic Sensor Technology for EAP Health Management, or even more broadly for IVHM for Sustainable EAP Aviation. Anticipated Benefits  This task performs the initial survey work needed to define a sensor approach to be combined with both on-going and future ARMD activities in IVHM for EAP applications program in sensing, diagnostics, and prognostics. IVHM for EAP is necessary for eventual system application, whether it be for safety, economic, efficiency, or performance reasons. Overall, new electric vehicles can be smarter, safer, and more efficient leveraging the difference in architecture  this work is a first step in providing sensor technology to enable this vision. 2. Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion. Milestone Date Project Initiation 11 6 23 Documentation of EAP Identified Fault Mechanisms (On-going Project) 12 6 23 Survey of Present EAP Fault Detection Approaches 3 30 24 Evaluation of Potential Alternate EAP Sensor Architectures 7 30 24 Summary Whitepaper and Draft Roadmap for EAP Sensor Development 9 1 24 This project should be evaluated upon whether a core understanding of the challenges of sensor detection in EAP systems has been clearly articulated, and potential approaches for future work coupling both sensors and diagnostics for EAP sustainable aviation have been reasonably identified for future program implementation potentially in FY25. It is also expected that coordination with other organizations related to, e.g., structural diagnostics or sustainable aviation prognostics, will be ongoing. 3. After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps? Where are the potential areas for transition? What follow-on research do you anticipate? The need for IVHM for Sustainable Aviation has been introduced to ARMD project management with positive response. In particular, it is our understanding that TTT Management has acknowledged the importance of this area and expressed interest for potential future funding. Assuming no project funding in FY24, this proposed project matures an understanding of the field and establishes a framework for a more expansive IVHM development in FY 25 if chosen by project management. 4. Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation  Three months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach is not feasible technically. You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot? What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue? Sensor development for health management of EAP systems is one component of what is necessary for possible sustainable aviation. An equally challenging area is health management for hydrogen powered vehicles especially those using cryogenic hydrogen. A NASA workshop identified a wide range of challenges associated with converting from conventional hydrocarbon fuel systems to hydrogen-based systems  8 . These include a significant range of safety concerns associated with hydrogen leakage, seals degradation, or structural embrittlement. If a change of direction is decided related to defining sensor technology for EAP applications, transition of the task to another aspect of sustainable aviation, hydrogen powered vehicles, would also have a significant impact on understanding the potential of IVHM for sustainable aviation. References 1. EAP is called out as a key part of Thrust 3 in the ARMD Strategic Implementation Plan  https   www.nasa.gov aeroresearch strategy 2. Overview of NASA's EAP Research for Large Subsonic Aircraft  https   ntrs.nasa.gov search.jsp?R 20170006235 3. Subsonic Single Aft Engine (SUSAN) Aircraft   Glenn Research Center   NASA 4. High Efficiency Megawatt Motor Preliminary Design,  Jansen et al. https   ntrs.nasa.gov citations 20190029589 5. NASA X-57 Project  https   www.nasa.gov aeroresearch X-57 technical index.html 6. D. Simon, Health Management Considerations for Electrified Aircraft Propulsion Systems , SAE E32 Aerospace Propulsion Health Management Committee Meeting March 29-31, 2022. https   ntrs.nasa.gov api citations 20220004260 downloads EAP HealthMangementConsideration  DSimon v2.pdf 7. NASA Advanced Air Vehicles Program, Advanced Air Transport Technology Project, Power and Propulsion Subproject 8. NASA s Meeting on Cryogenic Fuel Systems for Aircraft, NASA Glenn Research Center, Sept. 2022.

Prompt: Additive Manufacturing of Polyimde Composites for Battery Packaging
Description: Additive Manufacturing of Polyimde Composites for Battery Packaging   Introduction    Advances in lithium battery has made electrical propulsion a reality in the electrified aircrafts. Lightweight aluminum has been used preferentially chosen as the packaging material due to the large amount of power require to propel the electrified aircrafts.  the weight saving in engines often translates into 3 times of weight saving in the aircrafts, it is imperative to find alternative materials for battery packs other than aluminum. Additive manufacturing of lightweight, high temperature thermoset polyimide matrix composites (PMC) in place of aluminum casing for battery packaging will save 50  weight (Al PMC density ratio   2.7 1.3 g cc), ease the manufacturing process of complex shape and improve production efficiency. Furthermore, the boron nitride filled polyimide composite is thermally conductive but not electrically conductive, which may be a plus for battery packs to prevent the loss of electricity.       Update on Additive Manufacturing (AM) of Polyimide Composites by Principal Investigator (PI)   Traditional Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) or Fused Filament Fabrication (FFF) uses the extruded thermoplastic polymer filaments by melting the filaments to carry out the 3D printing following CAD files.  Conventional laser sintering (LS) is another 3D printing technique that builds 3D objects layer by layer using laser to selectively melt cross-section of a powdered thermoplastic polymers.  However, the resultant 3D objects are often weaker in their strength due to the lack of polymer inter-chain connection in the z-direction  thus, limiting their use temperature to  200 C based on the commercial thermoplastic polymers.      Previously this PI has developed a melt-processable thermoset polyimide RTM370 resin powder, which can be subjected to laser sintering (LS) at 180 C to build a 3D  Green  object, and subsequently post-cured at 371 C in an oven to fully crosslink the reactive terminal groups within the resin into a network with a glass transition temperature (Tg, softening temperature) of 370 C. A high temperature thermoset polyimide carbon fiber composite bracket with  300  C capability was additively manufactured by laser sintering (LS) for the 1st time in collaboration with U. of Louisville and funded by the Air Force during 2016-2018.                image003     FDM (FFF)     b) Laser sintering of resin powder               c) LS-printed carbon fiber composites                                                                                          Recently the PI has also demonstrated the feasibility of 3D-printing composite specimens with boron nitride   (BN) filled RTM385-SLS polyimide resin powder by laser sintering to afford  Green  dogbone specimens, which was subsequently post-cured at 343 C to afford a 3-dimensional network of BN-polyimide composites with a Tg of 395 C and a thermal conductivity of 0.7 W m-K with a 6-7   porocity   a major accomplishent under TTT and AATT funding.  Therefore, it is feassible to 3D-print thermally conductive but electrically insulating battery packs by laser sintering, using BN-filled thermoset polyimide resins.             Text Box                                                  Post-cured 343 C                                                                 LS-printed BN-PI composites                       Cured BN-PI composites            Proposed battery pack    Objective and Innovation of This Proposal  An Improved Fused Powder Fabrication (FPF)   Although PI s previous advance in the state-of-the art of laser sintering of thermoset polyimides with boron nitride fillers has certainly made additive manufacturing of thermally conductive, but electrically insulating battery packs an attainable goal. However, the required use of vast area of powder bed in laser sintering creates a large amount of unused resin powder in the peripheral surrounding the desirable object.  It is the objective of this proposal to initiate a Fused Powder Fabrication (FPF) of melt-processable BN-filled thermoset polyimide that will print the actual 3D object directly very similar to Fused Filament Fabrication (FFF) using thermoplastic filaments.  1) This fused thermoset polyimide powder fabrication approach will save cost on the valuable resin powder, and 2) the use of thermoset resin powder which can be further post-cure the as-printed  Green  object to achieve a higher use temperature than the commercial thermoplastic filaments can achieve.  It also eleminate the cost of extruding of filaments for FFF.   2) Project Plan   Using melt-processable thermoset polyimide resin powder, PI will collaborate with Hyrel 3D printing company to design a prototype Fused Powder 3D Printing Head that is capable of attaching to the existing commercial Hyrel 3D printer at GRC.  The goals are 1) demonstrate the capability of printing prototype 3D objects  such as square or dogbone-shaped tensile specimens. 2) print a prototype battery pack with high temperature of  300 C capability.          Task Description   Estimated completion Date   Award contract  Acquire resin   January, 2024   Design Trial for resin printing   June, 2024   Complete composite specimens   September, 2024   Characterization testing samples   November, 2024   Complete yearly report   December, 2024      3) Strategic Alignment    Battery packaging fits into STMD  Live  framework of human life support, advanced materials structures manufacturing. It also fits into GRC s Power and Energy Storage focus area. Battery packaging is the critical safety requirement for the success of power supply in space and electrified aircraft in aeronautic propulsion on Earth. The packaging materials typically prefer to be multifunctional  they must provide the necessary thermal and safety performance without significantly increasing the mass of the pack. Furthermore, additive manufacturing is an essential thrust in both STMD and GRC strategies.       Technology Readiness and Taxonomy           Starting TRL   2   Target End TRL   3           Primary TX   Additive manufacturing of polymer composites fits into                                 TX.12.2.1 Advanced Materials, Structures and Manufacturing.             Secondary TX  Battery components fit into TX.03.2.3  Aerospace Power and Energy Storage .       Technology Infusion or Transition Plan      When an additively manufactured composite battery pack is built, it will be transfer to Photovoltaic       Electrochemical Systems Branch (LEX) for evaluation in certain existing programs for space        power and electrified aircraft applications.       GRC s RTM imide resins are already licensed to Imitec Inc. as a commercial product, and a patent has        been filed in 2019 for the said laser sintering technology to make high temperature thermoset        composites with  300   C capability.      This same technology of fused powder fabrication of melt-processable thermoset polyimide composites       can also be used to build the Thermal Protection Systems (TPS) for reentry as these polyimide resin        have shown to have higher char yield than the state-or-the-art of phenolics.      4) Contingency Project Plan    In a hypothetical instance that the proposed fused powder fabrication (FPF) method was not successfully in demonstrating the technology advance after 4-month of trying, the team always has a fall back plan of 3D-printing the battery packs by laser sintering of RTM385-SLS polyimide resin with h-BN fillers, which has demonstrated its feasibility in the introduction section of this proposal.

Prompt: Modeling and mitigation of hydrogen embrittlement of GRX-810 alloy for hydrogen propulsion storage tanks
Description: Title    Modeling and mitigation of hydrogen embrittlement of GRX-810 alloy for hydrogen propulsion storage tanks          Cryogenic hydrogen fueled aircraft (under development at NASA GRC, Airbus, etc.) is one of the options to slash CO2 emissions related to air transportation. The main issue with using hydrogen in aircraft is its very low density  1 . Storing hydrogen in its liquid state (at cryogenic temperature) is one of the methods to increase the density. Liquid hydrogen storage tank needs to be resistant to hydrogen embrittlement and capable of structurally withstanding the temperatures of liquid hydrogen. Hydrogen embrittlement is a reduction in the ductility of the structural material (metal alloy) due to absorbed hydrogen. The main goal of this proposal is to investigate the effects of hydrogen absorption on ductility of the alloy GRX-810  2 , that is under development at NASA GRC. GRX-810 is a new breakthrough 3D-printable alloy with remarkable high temperature properties, e.g., creep. It is an oxide dispersion-strengthened alloy with a Ni-Co-Cr matrix. Preliminary tests of this alloy at cryogenic temperatures also show promising results (Yield Strength (YS) T 77K   0.9 GPa, Elongation to Failure (EF), or ductility T 77K   40 ). We note that recently developed Ni-Co-Cr-based Medium Entropy Alloys (MEAs) in general demonstrate exceptional mechanical properties at cryogenic temperatures, e.g., a remarkable increase in strength accompanied by a simultaneous increase in ductility (YS T 77K   0.7 GPa, EF T 77K   90 , FT T 77K   280 MPa m1 2), with decreasing deformation temperature from Room Temperature (RT) to cryogenic temperatures  3 . The diffusivity of hydrogen (e.g., along the grain boundaries), its segregation at lattice defects and the corresponding effects on deformation behavior (e.g., ductility) have not been quantified in the literature for Ni-Co-Cr-based MEAs, in general, and GRX-810 alloy, in particular. Atomistic modeling and simulations are perfectly suited to study the mechanisms of hydrogen embrittlement in full atomic detail and provide recommendations for novel alloy compositions that improve deformation behavior at cryogenic temperatures. Our proposed effort will be leveraged by the capabilities we already have. In particular, the Density Functional Theory- (DFT) informed simulation potential for Ni-Co-Cr, recently developed in our group, will be used for this project, along with the state-of-the-art atomistic simulation techniques (including ab-initio, molecular dynamics, kinetic Monte Carlo, and their combinations)  4, 5 .                First, we will fit the interatomic potential for Ni-Co-Cr-H (using the existent interatomic potential for Ni-Co-Cr, recently developed in our group), to enable realistic modeling of hydrogen diffusion and segregation at lattice defects in the material. Next, the segregation of hydrogen at lattice defects (e.g., grain boundaries) will be investigated, employing hybrid Molecular Dynamics   kinetic Monte Carlo (MD MC) simulations. And finally, the effects of hydrogen segregation on deformation behavior at cryogenic temperatures will be studied. In particular, a series of MD deformation tests will be carried out at cryogenic temperatures, varying the amount of hydrogen (and the amounts individual Ni, Co, Cr elements) in the simulation system containing a lattice defect, which would serve as a sink for hydrogen (e.g., a grain boundary). The successful accomplishment of the proposed work will lead to identifying the composition that most effectively improves the performance of the material at cryogenic temperatures.        The anticipated milestones will include the following     ab initio calculations for the H energetics in the Ni-Co-Cr alloys.   Interatomic potential for Ni-Co-Cr-H, suitable for simulation of hydrogen diffusion in the Ni-Co-Cr alloys.   Effects of hydrogen, segregated at a lattice defect (e.g., grain boundary) on deformation behavior at cryogenic temperatures.   Effects of Ni-Co-Cr composition (by varying the amount of individual Ni, Co, Cr elements in the simulation system) on the above behavior.           In the next step we will study the behavior of the composite system, containing hard oxide (Y2O3) particles embedded in the Ni-Co-Cr-based matrix, under deformation at cryogenic temperature. The interface between the oxide particle and Ni-Co-Cr-based matrix will possibly serve as a sink for the absorbed hydrogen. The effects of hydrogen segregation at this interface on deformation behavior at cryogenic temperatures will be studied, as well as the effects of solute atoms segregating at the interface on the above processes will be investigated and recommendations will be made regarding solute additions that maximally improve the deformation behavior.         Dedicated experiments will be carried out at NASA GRC to test the theoretically obtained results. If successful, the proposed project will enable a number of new Air Space applications for the GRX-810 alloy, e.g., as a structural material for cryogenic liquid hydrogen storage tanks (liquid hydrogen-fueled aircraft technology  under development at NASA GRC, etc.).           The results of MD MC simulations heavily depend on the quality of interatomic potential. Our initial choice is the Finnis-Sinclair semi-empirical potentials which are the computationally cheapest reasonable interatomic potentials for metals. However, if we find that this type of potential cannot reproduce our ab initio data obtained within first 3 months, we will switch to machine learning (ML) potentials.      References     1  A.J. Colozza, L. Kohout, Hydrogen storage for aircraft applications overview, 2002.    2  T.M. Smith, C.A. Kantzos, N.A. Zarkevich, B.J. Harder, M. Heczko, P.R. Gradl, A.C. Thompson, M.J. Mills, T.P. Gabb, J.W. Lawson, A 3D printable alloy designed for extreme environments, Nature  (2023) 1-6.    3  D. Liu, Q. Yu, S. Kabra, M. Jiang, P. Forna-Kreutzer, R. Zhang, M. Payne, F. Walsh, B. Gludovatz, M. Asta, Exceptional fracture toughness of CrCoNi-based medium-and high-entropy alloys at 20 kelvin, Science 378(6623) (2022) 978-983.    4  V.V. Borovikov, M.I. Mendelev, T.M. Smith, J.W. Lawson, Dislocation-assisted diffusion-mediated atomic reshuffling in the Kolbe mechanism for micro-twinning in Ni-based superalloys from molecular dynamics simulation, Scripta Materialia 232 (2023) 115475.    5  V.V. Borovikov, M.I. Mendelev, T.M. Smith, J.W. Lawson, Molecular dynamics simulation of twin nucleation and growth in Ni-based superalloys, International Journal of Plasticity  (2023) 103645.

Prompt: Energy Efficient, Out-of-Autoclave Manufacturing of Thermoplastic Composites for Aircraft Structures
Description: Title  Energy Efficient, Out-of-Autoclave Manufacturing of Thermoplastic Composites for Aircraft Structures. Background  Industry enthusiasm around thermoplastic composites (TPCs) is seeing a resurgence due to the potential for rapid manufacture of large aerospace structures. TPC matrices differ from the traditionally utilized thermosetting resins in that fabrication of a thermoplastic (TP) part requires only heating the material above its softening temperature and applying pressure to consolidate multiple layers of material. Currently, this process requires consolidation in a press or autoclave. The autoclave process for TPs has a substantial energy requirement for heating and cooling (processing temperatures are higher for TPs than thermosets) and autoclave press consolidation requires non-reusable, consumable materials. However, opportunity for manufacturing flexibility exists for TPs because the requirement for consolidating thermoplastics includes only heat and pressure. Of particular interest is out-ofautoclave consolidation. Problem  Out-of-autoclave or  in-situ  consolidation eliminates the energy intensive processing step of autoclave or press consolidation. To date, mechanical tests on parts manufactured by this process have shown a reduction in interlaminar strength. Previous work at the University of Delaware studied the physical mechanisms controlling laminate quality during in-situ consolidation by automated fiber placement (AFP). Process variables such as heat transfer, inter-ply contact time, and void reduction were modeled, tested, and quantified. The causes of inadequate consolidation were correlated with process, material, and machine parameters. The study concluded that heat transfer, lay-down speed, and consolidation pressure were the principle controllable process variables affecting laminate quality. (1,2) Current AFP and braiding processes do not support the time, temperature or pressure requirements to allow single-step production of aerospace quality composites. Has someone tried to solve the problem before. Out-of-autoclave processes have been attempted and is an area of active research but, to date, has been unsuccessful in meeting the mechanical properties achievable by traditional processing methods. The issue is partly due to time, temperature, and pressure requirements as described above. However, this cannot be the entire story as well-established fusion bonding processes such as induction welding and ultrasonic welding are very rapid in nature and still yield strong bonds. The fundamental difference between these welding processes and in-situ consolidation is in the number of heating and cooling cycles experienced per ply of the TPC during fabrication and consolidation. When carbon fiber thermoplastic plies are consolidated the air trapped between those layers is condensed by the consolidation pressure and absorbed in the matrix. In-situ consolidation by AFP, for example heats every ply as it is laid down, and several plies beneath. Each time a layer is reheated, trapped air expands, eventually leading to interlaminar void formation and reduced interlaminar mechanical properties. Where did they go wrong what is different about this approach  There is evidence to suggest that the issue with current approaches is related to the repeated heating and cooling of  consecutive plies during laminate fabrication. Work supported through a GRC 2022 Center Innovation Fund (CIF) has demonstrated that at least 8 plies of a braided preform can be successfully consolidated in one step by an induction welding approach, with dynamic crush properties comparable to autoclave consolidated parts.(3) Induction welding is a common thermoplastic joining technique and is effective for consolidating a braided composite architecture. Here we propose exploring ultrasonic welding as well, which provides a lower cost alternative and greater composite design flexibility than the induction welding process. A New Technology Report was submitted for this manufacturing approach within the NASA GRC NTR system and the work will be presented at the CAMX conference in Atlanta, GA. 1. Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion. We propose a building block approach to demonstrate this technology with the success metric including (1) laminate consolidation and (2) interlaminar mechanical properties that are comparable to press or autoclave processed composites. a. Literature and market survey to assess full environmental impact of in-situ consolidation. b. Establish in-house capability for in-situ consolidation. c. Coupon Subcomponent Coupon Data  apply building block approach to verify that consolidation and strength metrics can be met with single-step consolidation processes. This includes in-situ consolidation and mechanical tests. d. Budget  Costs for this project are associated with materials, manufacturing, and test. This includes a contract for welding (out of autoclave consolidation) while concurrently building the capability in-house. Previous work at GRC has demonstrated out of autoclave consolidation with induction welding. In this activity we would like to explore other options. 2. After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps? Where are the potential areas for transition? What follow-on research do you anticipate? This work will establish feasibility of the material class to enable sustainable aviation through reduced energy manufacturing costs. Next steps include but are not limited to the following. a. Evaluate feasibility through consolidation of a representative structure, i.e., variable thickness and diameter. b. Manufacture braided subscale fuselage and wings. Explore opportunity to leverage the AFRL DMAAPS (Design for Manufacture of Attritable Aircraft Primary Structure) program. In this program the AFRL manufactured a braided fuselage and wings of a small, UAM size aircraft with an out of autoclave thermosetting epoxy. Using their tool and design for manufacturing would allow direct comparison to cost, time, energy savings and consolidation quality of our process with that of a state-of-the-art material and process. Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation  Three months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial  proposed approach is not feasible technically. You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot? What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue? c. Fusion welding is a well-established process for joining thermoplastic composite parts. The novelty and risk associated with this proposal is using the fusion welding processes for consolidation purposes. In the event this is not technically feasible the project can pivot to documenting the strength and stiffness knockdown inherent to in-situ consolidation with the understanding that the applications may be acceptable for attritable aircraft and or unmanned vehicles. References 1. Gruber, M.B, et. al.  Thermoplastic In-Situ Placement Requires Better Impregnated Tapes and Tows , International SAMPE Technical Conference, 2012. 2. Cai, X.,  Determination of Process Parameters for the Manufacturing of Thermoplastic Composite Cones Using Automated Fiber Placement , Master s Thesis, Concordia University, 2012. 3. Cromer, A., et. al.,  Consolidation of Braided Carbon Fiber  Thermoplastic Tubes by Induction Heating , The Composites and Advanced Materials Expo (CAMX) Conference, Atlanta, GA. 2023

Prompt: High Lift High Load LPT Blade for Hybrid Engine
Description: TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS   TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE Title  High Lift High Load LPT Blade Design for Hybrid Turbine Engines Problem Statement Hybrid electric aircraft concepts, in general, offer the potential to downsize the core design of turbine engines, a concept currently under examination in the HyTEC program. Additionally, they provide operational benefits influenced by developments through TTT initiative. Both endeavors aim to enhance the efficiency of turbine engine components while increasing the overall bypass ratio of the aircraft. It is important to acknowledge that there are inevitable challenges associated with the downsizing of engine components, which must be addressed. While HyTEC focuses on promptly finding solutions to these challenges for near future, it is imperative to remain mindful of and proactively tackle the technical difficulties that might affect such efforts for the long term. On the other hand, new aircraft concepts like SUSAN and STARC-ABL aim to hybridize aircraft operations by employing turbine engines to power electric machines, thus further increasing the aircraft's overall bypass ratio. In order fully unlock the potential advantages offered by these conceptual aircraft architectures, it is imperative to comprehend and address the challenges and potential enhancements that will impact the turbine engine. In the turbine engine, high pressure, and low-pressure turbines (HPT and LPT) are responsible for providing the energy to run the high pressure and low-pressure compressors (HPC and LPC) respectively as well as providing excess energy for auxiliary components of the aircraft. the significance of the turbines, particularly the LPT, should not be underestimated 1 . Understanding the flow physics in LPT is vital and presents a significant challenge, leading to an intricate design process. On one hand, the LPT must perform optimally in high Reynolds number (    ) condition near sea level where maximum loading is required for take-off. On the other hand, the majority of the flight time is spent at high altitude cruise condition where the air density results in a lower      and lower momentum flow in LPT section2 . Low-     conditions can be particularly troublesome, as the lower momentum flow is prone to separation and transition effects due to the adverse pressure gradient experienced on the suction surface of the blade. Off-design operating conditions in the LPT section result in performance degradation due to this flow separation. This phenomenon known as Reynolds lapse3 can be intensified as the LPT gets smaller due to the smaller core of the future engines. Also, concepts seeking burning Hydrogen as a fuel will decrease      more and contributing to such losses even further. Multiple research efforts have addressed Reynolds lapse in LPTs with the most recent one conducted by air force research laboratory4 through optimal design of high lift high, high load low pressure turbine blades. All the current and previous works in this field seek to optimize the design of turbine blades in the traditional setting of gas turbine engines. The proposed work here seeks to utilize the design work conducted through TTT in Operability Influenced Design (OID) to investigate the possibility of understanding the design space for high-load high-lift LPT blades for hybrid electric engines. OID currently focuses on redesigning HPC component of a typical gas turbine engine by realizing the possible benefits of addition of electric motors to the engine enabled by Turbine Electrified Energy Management (TEEM) concept. Through this design practice it became evident that high-load blade design and optimization of turbine and compressor blades is required to fully realize any possible benefits which can be enabled by such control concepts or use of novel fuels such as hydrogen. Investigating such design spaces requires utilizing tools to allow for correct estimation of the flow field and flow transition that occurs at low-     in LPT. NASA currently lacks such crucial tools  and thus is incapable of conducting thorough analysis on the blade design to investigate correct benefits of these technologies on the engine components. OID mostly benefits the design of the compressor section which is tied to LPT and HPT closely. Moreover, there are similarities in the design process which can be translated from the turbine section to the compressor section. This work will to investigate the feasibility of designing high-load high-lift LPT blades for hybrid-electric aircrafts in cooperation with air force research laboratory through a one-year effort. Through this design process, significant expertise and blade design capability will be transferred to NASA work force. Approach The work will be divided in three phases with each contributing to a milestone. Milestone 1  2 months from actual start date (AS)   The requirements for the LPT blade design will be identified using a NASA    3 engine as a relevant open system which can be applied to both NASA OID effort and power extraction technical challenge under HyTEC. This milestone will be completed by defining the loading at each stage of the LPT according to a high lift, high load blade design approach. This milestone will be completed by providing a detailed requirements for each blade row of the    3 LPT. The substantial volume of data accessible for this engine design guarantees a high level of confidence in achieving this milestone. Milestone 2  10 months from AS   The first stage LPT blade design space will be explored based on the requirements identified in milestone 1. Turbine Design and Analysis System (TDAAS) will be used in this effort. It is a tool currently utilized by air force research laboratory to perform similar type of analysis for traditional turbine engines. TDAAS uses an airfoil generator along with a grid generator and flow solver to build the workflow for blade design. The various first stage LPT blade designs generated through this system will be evaluated aerodynamically first along with physical buildability. This milestone will be completed by designing the first stage blades for a hybrid-electric high-lift high-load LPT. In the event that we do not fully attain this milestone, it will provide us with a deeper understanding of the technical hurdles associated with LPT design necessitated by a reduction in the engine core size. This, in turn, will guide us in pinpointing areas for future research focus. Nevertheless, as a positive outcome, NASA stands to gain valuable expertise in blade design and optimization, which will prove indispensable for numerous ongoing research initiatives, including but not limited to addressing power extraction technical challenge in the HyTEC project, OID, SUSAN, and endeavors related to thermal management for energy extraction from the engine core. Milestone 3  12 months from AS   The blade design achieved in milestone 2 will inform the researchers on the feasibility of the high lift, high load blade design for the other four stages of the LPT. While a thorough redesign of the blades is required to accurately assess any possible benefits in LPT, it will not be in the scope of this work. However, analytical methods can be utilized to estimate such benefits and investigate the possibility of reducing the stages in this LPT. This milestone will provide an analysis of the overall benefits to the LPT design through the analysis of the engine system with a redesigned LPT in NPSS. If Milestone 2 is successfully accomplished, this task can be carried out using analytical methods based on the principles of turbomachinery design. However, if the second milestone is only partially achieved or not completed, it will provide valuable insights into the system-level constraints when designing high-load LPTs. This, in turn, will enhance the realism of evaluating new aircraft or engine concepts. Upon its successful conclusion, this endeavor will primarily enable NASA to acquire the knowledge and resources essential for in-depth blade design of turbine engine components. While initially the licenses for software in this  effort should be purchased, it is the goal of this work to subsequently integrate these methodologies with NASA's internal tools, including NPSS, OTAC, FUN3D, and others, to empower researchers in the design or redesign of turbomachinery blades. This approach will facilitate the development of innovative conceptual architectures and the tools required to effectively evaluate potential advantages stemming from new technologies. Furthermore, this work will offer valuable insights for the OID and SUSAN projects, as well as forthcoming projects focused on the assessment of new fuels and engine concepts. Special Scenario "If it proves unfeasible to design new high-lift, high-load blades, the project can easily shift its focus towards the redesign of the compressor within the OID work. This effort aimed to develop a new HPC design for the    3 by leveraging the advantages of adding electric machines to the engine. In this context, the ongoing work can reallocate its resources to delve deeper into the aforementioned effort, exploring the redesign of one or multiple stages within the new HPC concept. While the primary goal of this effort is to attain expertise and tools for blade design, it will still contribute to the project's success. References 1. Walker, G.J., 1993. The role of laminar-turbulent transition in gas turbine engines  A discussion. 2. McQuilling, M.W., 2007. Design and validation of a high-lift low-pressure turbine blade (Doctoral dissertation, Wright State University). 3. Wisler, D.C., 1998, June. The technical and economic relevance of understanding boundary layer transition in gas turbine engines. In Minnowbrook II, 1997 Workshop on Boundary Layer Transition in Turbomachines (pp. 53-64). NASA CP-1998-206958. 4. Clark, J.P., Paniagua, G. and Cukurel, B., 2023, June. On the Development of High Lift, High Work Low-Pressure Turbines. In Turbo Expo  Power for Land, Sea, and Air (Vol. 87097, p. V13BT30A029). American Society of Mechanical Engineers.

Prompt: Dual Hydrogen-Jet Fuel Aircraft - a path to zero emissions
Description: TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS   TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL Title  Dual Hydrogen-Jet Fuel Aircraft   a path to zero emissions 1. The work will build upon the dual hydrogen-jet fuel aircraft concept first demonstrated in 1956 to enable a path to low emissions, which reduced demands on renewable energy and infrastructure, towards zero emissions. The dual hydrogen-jet fuel aircraft concept retains the wing tanks and economically adds hydrogen to a 737-class single aisle offloading Jet A to retain the same range enabling flexible aircraft operations and paths forward. Dual Hydrogen-Jet Fuel aircraft with only 2080km of zero emission range, or 30  hydrogen by energy can reduce emissions by 50  can be raised to an astonishing 97.5  at lower and more stable fuel costs than SAF and Jet A. The low energy per unit volume of hydrogen introduces significant aviation challenges for 100  LH2 fueled aircraft to economically meet the stringent mass, volume, and safety requirements and the first order optimum is  30  LH2 by energy. The 97.5  U.S. emissions reduction will require a change in the airline business model. The dual hydrogen-jet fuel concept is a significant departure from the 2021 U.S. Aviation Climate Action Plan based on drop-in carbon-based Sustainable Aviation Fuels (SAF) and most importantly, is not a  farther term technology  that also retains the current Aero portfolio to offset increases in cost. The U.S. Climate Action Plan stated that there was no expectation that LH2 aircraft would make a significant contribution towards achieving net-zero emissions by 2050. The much slower adoption of hydrogen fuel was also based primarily upon the need to access renewable energy and to develop ground storage and distribution systems, and to a lesser extent, upon the need mature electric and hydrogen technologies and to tackle several other technical and safety challenges. The 2020 European Hydrogen Aircraft study cited a derived need for  4300GW for 100  SAF vs 1450 GW for 100  LH2--likely overlooked--while 30  LH2 would require 435 GW, a ten-fold decrease, but must add back liquefaction energy. By relying on off-grid and excess energy, LH2 production will not have to rely on grid provided renewable energy. Note that plant based SAF may only achieve 25  carbon emission reduction,  4X less than carbon free hydrogen and SAF via direct air capture. At present, 2050 SAF goals are unstainable beyond  not achieving the net-zero by 2050 goal . In general, limited supply SAF (HEFA) is the lowest cost while unbounded supply based on direct air capture  a massive green prize  plus green LH2 (PtL e-kerosene) is the highest cost fuel. SAF s have predicted costs 2-10x the cost of Jet A, creating a significant risk to national and world security, in an attempt to limit aircraft and infrastructure modifications, besides incorrectly assuming SAF would require less renewable energy and that off-grid, excess renewable energy is not available, which would favor hydrogen. The U.S. Climate Action Plan correctly identified that Aviation  must change the fuel  to meet net zero goals and that technology alone showcased in the in EPFD and TTBW X-66A demonstrators would  not  be sufficient. In  contrast , hydrogen aircraft would become the pull technology in fewer higher energy locations to help eliminate grid bottlenecks and reduce emissions in the hard to decarbonize industries. In contrast, rather than remove fuselage and engines from a MD-90 to form the TTBW X66A, adding hydrogen tanks could fly the same number of PAX with hydrogen plumbed to the rear-mounted engines. The Airbus A380 LH2 demonstrator adds a 3rd hydrogen engine cantilevered from the fuselage along with the hydrogen fuel system and tank. In contrast, while the truss braced wing is an excellent design for battery and 100  hydrogen aircraft since  no energy will be carried in the wings, the lower amount of jet fuel carried must be further considered in a dual hydrogen-jet fuel concept. In the proposed work, hydrogen must be approached from a systems level, because it won t work unless you have all the pieces to make it work from an operating system. Since hydrogen production results from off-grid and or excess renewable energy, dual fuel does not have to be dependent on grid green energy and wait 30 years. Conversely, objectives are achieved when a bottoms-up understanding of the assumptions, physics, and resources including those outside NASA s domain are tracked, compared, and traded versus vehicle system goals requiring proper communication insight, including what happens when projects are not priorities or technology risks are not properly identified, and subsystems are not compatible. Safety cannot be assessed without integrated designs and hardware. Indeed, many others recognize one must limit the need for renewable energy and potential infrastructure buildup and dual fuel enables aircraft flexibility across the globe while significantly reducing emissions economically. UH   Boeing and Airbus are likely to develop a replacement for these venerable models (single aisles dominated by the B737 and A320) for entry into service in the mid-2030s. The only way aviation can meet Paris Agreement emissions targets is if the new single aisle airplanes are hydrogen powered.   A hydrogen single aisle does not need to be a radical new design  an unstretched MD-90 or a  Transatlantic Concept  flying the same number of PAX as a A320 needs to be examined, as well as adding the unducted fan ultra-high-bypass engine, to name but a few paths to explore. A 100  hydrogen powered aircraft increases fuel volume over four-fold versus a conventional aircraft occupying cargo and passenger space, while 30  hydrogen by energy can provide 50 to 97.5  reduction in emissions via 2080km of zero emissions range to tackle the easy part of the range sooner and more economically with 9 times less energy than ekerosine Power-to-Liquid (plus liquefaction energy) at 2 to 10 times less cost than SAF. The dual fuel concept--ready for short term demonstrations as there are no insurmountable problems--opens up the design space for further out technologies including those beyond NASA and all of the areas identified in this Green Aviation New work  Alternative Propulsion, Aircraft Design, Materials and Manufacturing, Air Traffic Management, Emission Control, Sustainable Infrastructure, and Contrail Formation requiring  100Ms not  M. Dual Hydrogen-Jet Fuel aircraft with 14  hydrogen by weight can reduce emissions safely by 50 to 97.5  to supplement SAF reductions at less costs, and more importantly, will reduce demands on renewable energy and infrastructure. The work will perform studies of the dual  hydrogen-jet fuel concepts and many key components, describe key SAF challenges and limitations, outline the pathways, challenges, and infrastructure changes for dual fuel aircraft and technologies to speed the transition safely and economically to beyond net zero. 2. The work will further examine the strengths and weaknesses of the dual fuel concept to reduce emissions by 50  sooner and more economically than SAF within the time frame of the award and resources provided. Benefits and opportunities for dual hydrogen-jet fuel electric propulsion will be described. The milestone is to provide sufficient justification that leads to a demonstration path or to be unlikely usurped by alternative approaches. Many innovative design details and the 97.5  justification are not described due to proposal limits but will be further developed as bottoms up design is required for system assessments, to address safety. 3. The limited resource Green Aviation New Work is only a path to zero emissions which will require  Bs to place aircraft into service, identify the limitations and hence opportunities for further R D in an expanded design space that transcends NASA a significant effort beyond the PI abilities to raise the TRL. Before this work is completed, NASA could outsource the same work to a University Led Initiative, add a task to the Truss Braced Wing Demonstrator, have another organization help develop a key technology( e.g., tanks), or collaborate further with other agencies to develop the infrastructure, to name just a few. 4. If the concepts are not technically feasible, it then creates the opportunity to examine or ignore alternatives and or breakdown current approach to the key challenges likely presenting opportunities to other disciplines. Proposal constraints prevents addressing many detailed design issues. Innovation occurs when folks presented with a problem ask,  how may we look at this differently . How one pivots depends on many factors, but especially on how complete the current approach was examined. With so many areas to investigate listed above, it will require a re-examination of the path forward to first expand and then contract the trade space with data. Another factor is that SMEs are not always correct, and often do not present limitations clearly, so it s important to understand the rationale for this assessment, especially if new data methods and or a breakthrough overcomes the limitation. In the case of dual fuel, the most obvious alternative approach is SAF via DAC that becomes sustainable or funded by DOD for National Security, which is only a small fraction of NASA domain, so this is a limited opportunity. A logical pivot would be toward technology to reduce fuel burn to reduce resources required for zero emissions. The pivot would have to make an impact since there are no rewards for failure in a very mature and challenging industry since the story being told in general is that one shifts to line or project management. Further developing AI, propulsion, electrical, materials, and other discipline and technology skills almost always help develop paths forward so will also be included in the pivot options-perhaps better than let the team understand that path forward is unlikely.

Prompt: Computational Design of Superconductors for Superconducting Aircraft Propulsion Motors
Description: TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS   TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE INSTRUCTIONS Please do not include your name or other contact information in this form or in the file name. Please limit the submission to 3 pages with 11 pt font or bigger. Answer the questions below. Requested resources will be addressed in the form submission and do not need to be addressed in this template. RESPOND TO PROMPTS BELOW Title  Computational Design of Superconductors for Superconducting Aircraft Propulsion Motors 1. Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated benefits). Address any or all of the following questions (if relevant)  What problem are you solving? Has someone tried to solve this problem before? Where did they go wrong? What is different about your approach? If no one has attempted to solve this problem before, why not? How does your proposed work transform current capabilities, tools methods or state-of-the art approaches? If successful, what does your proposed work enable that currently is unattainable? Please include references citations to back up claims where appropriate. All electric airflights offer climate-neutral aviation by greatly reducing carbon emission  1 . However, the traditional electric motor is limited by its power density, i.e., the power to weight ratio. Superconducting aircraft propulsion motors have the potential of achieving power densities 2-3 times the state of the art for machines in the megawatt (MW) or larger class with   99  efficiency  2 . This requires superconductors to carry very strong current, and therefore, the superconductor coils  3,4  must be kept well below its superconducting critical temperature. Currently, the high-temperature superconductors (HTSCs), in particular, cuprates (such as GdBa2Cu3O7 films)  5  are used in such motors and must be cooled to below 20 K by liquid hydrogen, although their critical temperatures are well above 77 K, the boiling point of nitrogen. However, liquid hydrogen is not only expensive but also poses a substantial risk to safety. Previous researches in this field have been focused on designing new structures of the superconducting motors while employing the existing cuprate HTSCs. Though this approach has led to operational superconducting motors with much improved energy to weight ratio compared with the traditional ones, the target MW and larger class are still beyond reach without considering new superconductors which can carry stronger current and or at higher temperatures. Such researches on new superconductors require totally different technical expertise than what the engineering groups working on this filed usually have. In this project, we propose to computationally design novel superconductors, in addition to current researches on designing novel motor structures. The combination of these two approaches has the potential of reaching the desired energy density at a much higher output power scale. Furthermore, previous theoretical researches  6  on superconductors have been mostly dedicated on predicting the critical temperatures  !, and very few efforts  7,8  have been spent to consider and calculate the critical current density as a function of temperature and to find out superconductors with higher critical current.  Technically, the critical current density  ( ) has the same temperature dependence as that of the superconducting gap amplitude  ( ), and  ( ) can be obtained theoretically by solving the coupled integration equations for superconducting and total charge densities, respectively, which are a direct consequence of the well-known mean-field BCS theory  9 . To obtain  ( ) and  ( ), firstly, one has to calculate the critical temperature  !, which depends on a number of physical quantities according to the BCS relation and the McMillan s analysis  10    !     1.45 exp    1           (1   0.62 ) 7  .   . Here   is the Debye temperature,    the Coulomb repulsion, and   the electron-phonon coupling constant. These three key quantities are also needed to obtain the parameters in the coupled integration equations. We note that nowadays  ,    and   can be computed by solving the quantum mechanical equations (first- -principles electronic structure calculations) routinely and accurately, and the calculated  ! based on the above McMillian s expression can be quantitatively comparable with the measured data. Thus, a breakthrough has been made in superconductivity research, and one prominent example is the experimental discoveries of the high-T superconductor SH3 under high pressure after the first-principles calculations were carried out. In 2014, Duan et al.  11  predicted  ! of 200 K under a pressure of 160-200 GPa for SH3, while in 2015 Drozdov et al.  12  measured  ! of 203 K under 160 GPa. Besides first-principles calculations, machine learning and data mining  13  have been successfully applied to find new superconductors and to determine their  !  14 . Our group members have employed, tailored and developed both first-principles and high-throughput computational tools to compute lattice vibrations (phonons) and electron-phonon coupling in metals and insulators. These tools can be used to accurately evaluate  ,    and   and to fast screen materials by efficiently estimating these quantities. Furthermore, our group members have used machine learning and data mining methods to study battery materials and biomaterials, and this expertise is directly transferrable for superconductor research. Superconductivity research requires close collaborations between theory and experiments since theory alone or experiments alone are prone to errors and false claims  15,16 . Our experimental collaborator, Prof. Chen in University of Houston, is a world-renowned expert on HTSC and topological superconductors  17-19 . Combining our theory computation and their materials synthesis and characterization will be the key for us to find out superconductors which can carry stronger electric current at higher T for making aircraft motors. As summarized in Figure 1 on the right, there exist five different types of superconductors forming more than 12,000 known superconductors listed in the SuperCon database  20 . Guided by the existing data, known empirical rules and experimental observations, we will employ the high-throughput screening and machine learning and data mining to find out potential candidates. Then we will apply the accurate first-principles methods to compute  ' and  ( ) for these materials. Finally, our theoretical findings of the most promising candidates will be synthesized and measured by our experimental collaborators. Fig. 1  The major advances in superconductivity vs year  6 . 2. Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion. During the first year of the work, we will focus solely on employing, developing, and examining firstprinciples methods to calculate the superconducting critical temperature  ! and the critical current density  ( ). As mentioned previously, methods to compute the associated crucial physical quantities of  ,    and   have been implemented in many popular first-principles programs such as VASP  21  and ABINIT  22 , but we need to program the code to solve the coupled integration equations to obtain the superconducting gap amplitude,  ( ), and then  ( ). However, reaching the desired accuracy for    and   is still very challenging, since multiple approximations are involved and we need to carefully examine these approximate models and numerical convergence for different types of superconductors. Some existing models need to be further improved or simplified to increase accuracy or efficiency so that these quantities can be calculated within certain tolerable errors and reasonable computation cost. The anticipated milestones are the errors in the calculated critical current and critical temperature are within 50  and 25 , respectively, compared with experimental data for a few prototypical superconductors belonging to five different types as illustrated in Figure 1, with particular emphasis on calculating and comparing critical current for superconductors currently used in superconducting aircraft motors. 3. After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps? Where are the potential areas for transition? What follow-on research do you anticipate? After this work is finished, we shall possess the computational capabilities of accurately evaluating the critical current density in different types of superconductors from first principles. Next, we will employ and develop the high-throughput tools to compute these quantities, so that we can do fast screening among the existing 12,000 superconductors and novel possible compositions. The machine learning and data mining methods will also be built and tested, as an alternative approach to find out potential candidates for further theoretical investigations using the first-principles methods. Then we will combine these computational approaches with experimental measurements to find out either existing or new superconductors, which can carry twice of the maximum current the present HTSC films can do and or which can carry the same maximum current as before at temperatures higher than 77 K. Twice of maximum current would increase the output power density of the aircraft motors by 300 . 4. Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation  Three months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach is not feasible technically. You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot? What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue? After three months into this work, if we find that the initial proposed approach is not feasible technically, we will first identify the cause. The approach based on first-principles calculations that we described in the first session has been implemented in many codes and has been tested for numerous superconductors with varying degrees of accuracy on the calculated  !. Large errors in  ! normally means that the calculated  ,    and   are not sufficiently accurate, which will also severely affect the accuracy in the predicted  ( ), when solving the coupled integration equations. The Deby temperature   normally can be predicted very accurately, while the Coulomb repulsion    and electron-phonon coupling constant   are much harder to be obtained with sufficient accuracy. We will (1) examine and improve the theoretical models and numerical convergence  (2) use machine learning and data mining techniques to obtain these two values from the SuperCon database and other existing theoretical results and measured data  (3) employ phenomenological models, which are based on physics considerations, but whose parameters are often fitted to measured data.
